revision.text: {{BLP sources| date= March 2014}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = [[معمم (Sufism)|Sheikh]] | name = Habib Ali Al-Jifri | honorific_suffix = | image = HabibAli.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = | native_name = الحبيب علي زين العابدين الجفري | native_name_lang = ar | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1971|4|16|mf=y }}{{cite book|first=Thomas|last=Pierret|title=Religion and State in Syria: The Sunni Ulama from Coup to Revolution|page=127| ISBN=1107026415}} | birth_place = [[Jeddah]], [[Saudi Arabia]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | residence = [[Abu Dhabi]], [[United Arab Emirates]] | nationality = | other_names = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Ulama|Islamic scholar]] | years_active = | employer = | organization = Tabah Foundation | known_for = | notable_works = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = [[Sheikh#Religious usage|Shaykh]] | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse = | children = | relatives = | awards = | website = {{URL|http://www.alhabibali.com/en/}} | footnotes = }} '''Ali Zain al-Abidin al-Jifri''' ({{lang-ar|الحبيب علي زين العابدين الجفري}}; born April 16, 1971) is a Sunni/[[Sufi]][http://www.aquila-style.com/focus-points/spirituality/scholar-spotlight-sufi-kind-love/76404/ Aquila Style: "Scholar spotlight: Habib Ali al-Jifri, a Sufi kind of love" - By Omar Shahid] 21st August 2014 [[Ulama|Islamic scholar]] and spiritual educator located in the [[United Arab Emirates]]. He is the founder of Tabah Foundation (مؤسسة طابـة),Gerhard Böwering, Patricia Crone, Mahan Mirza, The Princeton Encyclopedia of Islamic Political Thought, p 600. {{ISBN|0691134847}}http://www.tabahfoundation.org/en/ a research institute based in [[Abu Dhabi]], [[UAE]].Philip Lewis, Young, British and Muslim (Continuum 2007), p 76. ==Early life== Ali Zain al-Abidin al-Jifri was born in the city of Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, on 16 April 1971Thomas Pierret, Religion and State in Syria: The Sunni Ulama from Coup to Revolution, p 127. {{ISBN|1107026415}} (20th Safar 1391 AH). Al-Jifri is a direct descendant of the Islamic prophet [[Muhammad]] through his grandson Hussein.Yvonne Y Haddad, Educating the Muslims of America, p. 151. {{ISBN|0199705127}} ==Awards and recognition== In 2009, Al-Jifri was listed 37th in the world’s [http://www.rissc.jo/docs/muslim500-1M-lowres3.pdf 500 most influential Muslims] by [[Georgetown University]]’s The Prince Al-Waleed Bin Talaal Center for Muslim-Christian Understanding and [[Royal Islamic Strategic Studies Centre]] of Jordan.http://themuslim500.com/profile/habib-ali-zain-al-abideen-al-jifri He was a recipient of the Eugen Biser award in 2008 for his contribution to the document [[A Common Word Between Us and You]].Joseph Nnabugwu, Analyzing A Common Word Between Us Muslims and You Christians: A Critical Discourse Analysis, p 101. {{ISBN|1462853072}} ==See also== *[[Ba'Alawi]] *[[Sunnism]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == *[http://www.alhabibali.com/en Official Website] {{Shafi'i scholars}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jifri, Habib Ali}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Arabs]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian Sunni Muslims]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian Sunni Muslim scholars of Islam]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian television personalities]] [[Category:Hashemite people]] [[Category:Shafi'is]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Annie Land O'Berry | image = Annie Land O'Berry.jpg | birth_date = May 28, 1885 | birth_place = [[Edgecombe County, North Carolina]] | death_date = February 4, 1944 | death_place = [[Baltimore, Maryland]] | alma_mater = Littleton College, [[William Peace University]], [[Columbia University]] }}
'''Annie Land O'Berry''' (1885-1944) was an activist, relief worker, and philanthropist from [[North Carolina]]. O'Berry was a native to North Carolina, growing up in [[Edgecombe County, North Carolina|Edgecombe County]] on a farm with her family. She was involved in women's clubs and an open member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic party]]. More specifically, O’Berry's endeavors in the North Carolina Emergency Relief Association, [[North Carolina Democratic Party]], [[League of Women Voters]], and the Women's Missionary Society at her local [[Presbyterianism|Presbyterian Church]] demonstrated her dedication to serving her community. As an academic, O'Berry was named the first honor graduate from Peace University.
== Early Life and Education == Annie Land O’Berry was born on May 28th 1885 in [[Edgecombe County, North Carolina|Edgecombe County]], North Carolina to V.W. and Mary Dawson Mayo Land. O’Berry grew up on her family plantation and enjoyed playing outdoor sports until the age of 13, when her parents died and she moved to live with her her older sister in [[Littleton, North Carolina|Littleton]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ncpedia.org/biography/oberry-annie-land|title=O'Berry, Annie Land|last=|first=|date=|website=[[NCpedia]]|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-04}}</ref> From a young age, O’Berry was interested in and excelled at school. In grammar school O’Berry attained high marks and continued on to study at Littleton College.<ref name=":2">{{cite book |last1=Walker |first1=Harriette Hammer |title=Busy North Carolina women |date=1931 |publisher=H.H. Walker |url=http://digital.ncdcr.gov/cdm/ref/collection/p249901coll37/id/3372 |accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref>{{Rp|23-24}} She then attended the [[William Peace University]], graduating as the first honor graduate.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://nchistorytoday.wordpress.com/2014/02/04/annie-oberry-new-deal-administrator/|title=Annie O’Berry, New Deal Administrator|last=|first=|date=2014-02-04|work=[[North Carolina Department of Natural and Cultural Resources|This Day in North Carolina History]]|access-date=2018-09-04|language=en-US}}</ref>
After graduation, O’Berry moved in with her brother, Edward Land, in [[Kinston, North Carolina|Kinston]]. There, O’Berry was an active member of the [[Presbyterian Church]] where she organized Sunday School and was chairman of the Women's Missionary Society.<ref name=":2" />{{Rp|23-24}} On December 14th, 1909 Annie Land married Thomas O’Berry and soon after they moved to [[Goldsboro, North Carolina|Goldsboro]], North Carolina.<ref name=":1" /> Throughout her career, O’Berry advocated for education and aspired to end adult illiteracy.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jOAqWMwsgFcC&dq=annie+o'berry+unc&source=gbs_navlinks_s&printsec=frontcover#v=snippet&q=O'Berry&f=false|title=The Power of Femininity in the New South: Women's Organizations and Politics in North Carolina, 1880-1930|last=Sims|first=Anastatia|date=1997|publisher=Univ of South Carolina Press|isbn=9781570031786|language=en}}</ref> In addition, as O’Berry focused on relief in her own community, she took a course on social work at [[Columbia University]].<ref name=":1" />
== Philanthropy == While living with her brother in Kinston, Annie Land O’Berry was very active in the North Carolina Federation of Women's Clubs. She became the first chairman of the Anti-Tuberculosis Committee of [[Wayne County, North Carolina|Wayne County]] where she was the president for two years. O’Berry gave her time and effort to what was then called the Charity Organization of Goldsboro.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=Tar Heel Women|last=Rogers|first=Lou|publisher=Warren Publishing Co.|year=1949|isbn=|location=Edwards and Broughton Co., Raleigh, North Carolina|pages=273-277}}</ref> She later went to Columbia University in order to learn more about this type of work.<ref name=":1" /> O’Berry also helped her father-in-law, Captain Nathan O’Berry of Goldsboro, raise over $5,000.00 to help white collar people during the depression. As a result, Governor Angus McLean appointed her to the Commission to Study County Government and the North Carolina Historical Commission. O’Berry also worked in the Goldsboro Club in Women's Club Work. She was elected vice-president of the State Federation in 1923 and, in 1927, was elected president.
O’Berry's literacy committee sponsored an Educational Pilgrimage to [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]]. It was recognized as one of the most outstanding projects of adult education in the [[United States]].<ref name=":3" /> She was later named the vice-chair of the state executive committee of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] in 1930.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=McGuire|first=John Thomas|date=2012|title=The Boundaries of Democratic Reform: Social Justice Feminism and Race in the South, 1931–1939|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/23795647|journal=The Journal of Southern History|volume=78|issue=4|pages=887–912}}</ref> Three years later, in 1933, O’Berry became one of the few women to administer a state emergency relief agency as she became the administrator of the Civil Works Commission. The Civil Works Commission later became the North Carolina Emergency Relief Administration (NCERA).<ref name=":3" /> O’Berry continued to remain in-charge of an offshoot of NCERA, called the Rural Rehabilitation Corporation, until her death. This offshoot provided loans to farmers. Through her diplomacy, O’Berry provided both direct and indirect relief to many citizens.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ncdcr.gov/blog/2016-12-21/annie-oberry-new-deal-administrator|title=Annie O'Berry, New Deal Administrator|last=|first=|date=|website=NC.GOV|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 20, 2018}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.uncpress.org/book/9781469629018/dictionary-of-north-carolina-biography/|title=Dictionary of North Carolina Biography {{!}} William S. Powell {{!}} University of North Carolina Press|work=University of North Carolina Press|access-date=2018-10-02|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Legacy == Annie Land O’Berry worked to help clubwomen overcome indifference to civic responsibility. She inspired them to be civic-minded and to work for the advancement of adult education. She was viewed as ‘the little soldier,’ ‘relief lady,’ and a symbol of ‘food for the hungry, homes for the weary and a new chance for the discouraged.’<ref name=":3" /> Although she had no children of her own, O’Berry raised her grand-nephew and grand-niece as her own. <ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" />
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == <!-- [[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Peace_University]] -->
<!--- Categories ---> [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:People from Edgecombe County, North Carolina]] [[Category:Activists from North Carolina]] [[Category: Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:William Peace University alumni]] [[Category:Philanthropists]]

revision.text:
[[image:Ataa Oko, his third wife with a battleship coffin about 1960.jpg|thumb|Ataa Oko and his third wife, with a coffin in the form of a battleship, about 1960]]
'''Ataa Oko''' (c. 1919 - 9 December 2012)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artbrut.ch/en/21034/vie-collection|title=Collection de l'Art Brut|website=Art Brut|access-date=2018-04-19|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161130061054/http://www.artbrut.ch/en/21034/vie-collection/|archive-date=2016-11-30|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> was a [[Ghana|Ghanaian]] builder of [[Figurative Palanquin in Ghana|figurative palanquins]] and [[fantasy coffin]] and at over 80 years of age he became a painter of [[Art Brut]].
==Biography== [[File:Drawing by Ataa Oko 2010.jpg|thumb|Figurative palanquin, drawing of Ataa Oko 2010]] Ataa Oko was born around 1919 in the coastal town of La, [[Ghana]]. He never went to school, but worked since he was about 13 years old as a fisherman. Later his family sent him on the cocoa plantations in the Ashante Region. From 1936 to 1939 he was trained as a carpenter in Accra. From 1939 to 1970 he worked in numerous temporary employments.
According to [[Regula Tschumi]], Ataa Oko started to build figurative coffins around 1945.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://lepoignardsubtil.hautetfort.com/tag/cercueils%20du%20ghana|title=cercueils du ghana : Le Poignard Subtil|website=lepoignardsubtil.hautetfort.com|language=fr|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> He had been inspired by the [[Figurative palanquin|figurative palanquins]] he had seen in Accra. These palanquins were used by the Ga chiefs already at the beginning of the 20th century. The palanquins were built in the form of the respective family symbols which the Ga chiefs were using.<ref>Regula Tschumi: "The Figurative Palanquins of the Ga. History and Significance", in: ''[[African Arts (journal)|African Arts]]'', Vol. 46, Nr. 4, 2013, pp. 60-73.</ref> Around 1960 Ataa Oko opened his own coffin and palanquin workshop in La.
The last years of his life, Ataa Oko was retired and hardly built coffins any more. Around 2005 the former carpenter started to draw. His graphic art practice was boorn as a result of his meeting with Regula Tschumi who was making a research about the figurative coffins of the Ga. Looking for information about this art form the ethnologist asked Ataa Oko to draw his former works he had made some 50 years ago.<ref>Lucienne Peiry: The Flute of Ataa Oko. In: Outsider Art, Vol. 3, Shanghai University Press, 2016, p. 22-33.</ref> Ataa Oko's graphic work developed continuously. When he died in 2012, he left behind a comprehensive body of work that give a fascinating insight not only into the life of the artist, but also into the religious life and culture of the Ga people.<ref>Regula Tschumi: Ataa Oko. A glimpse inside the amazing world of Ghanaian funerals and how the carpenter Ataa Oko became an artist, online magazine Interwoven: the fabric of things.</ref>
Ataa Oko's coffins and drawings were first exhibited in the group show "Six Feet Under" at the Kunstmuseum Berne 2006 and 2010/11 he had first one-man show in the well known [[Collection de l'art brut]] in Lausanne.<ref>''Ataa Oko'', exhibition catalogue, 2010, ed. [[Collection de l'art brut]], Lausanne.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.letemps.ch/QueryResult#|title=Recherche - Le Temps|website=Le Temps|language=fr|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref>
[[File:Ataa Oko and Kudjo Affutu with Oko's red coq coffin 2009. Foto Regula Tschumi.JPG|thumb| Ataa Oko and [[Kudjoe Affutu]] with Okos red rooster coffin 2009]]
== Single and group exhibitions == * 2017/18. [[Collection de l'art brut]], Lausanne: ''3ème Biennale de l'art brut: Corps''. * 2017. ANO Gallery Accra: "Accra: Portraits of A City". * 2014. MUT Museum of the University Tübingen: "Diesseits-Jenseits-Abseits". * 2012. MEN Musée ethnographique Neuchâtel ''Hors-Champs''. * 2011/12. [http://www.mycelium-fr.com/#/expositions-finlande-1/3857959 ''Miracles of Africa''], Hämeenlinna Art Museum, [[Hämeenlinna]] and [[Oulu Museum of Art]], Oma, Finland<ref>ARS 11, Nykytaiteen museo Kiasma Kiasma, Museum of Contemporary Art. Artists: Ataa Oko, 1919, Ghana, [[Collection de l'art brut]], Lausanne. Franck Lundangi, 1958, Angola, Artist’s own collection, Briare. Ghana Posters, Hand painted movie posters, Pascal Saumade’s collection, Paris; Paul Amar, 1919, Algeria. From 15 April to 27 November 2011. Mannerheiminaukio 2, Helsinki. www.kiasma.fi. SATELLITE EXHIBITION "Stars of Africa": Hämeenlinna Art Museum. From 20 May to 11 September 2011. OMA – Oulu Museum of Art. From 24 September 2011 to 8 January 2012. Curators: Tuula Karjalainen, Ph.D., curator; Laurent Danchin, art critic, journalist, curator;</ref> * 2011. Sainsbury Centre for Visual Arts, University of East Anglia, Norwich. [https://web.archive.org/web/20111120040332/http://www.scva.co.uk/exhibitions/current/index.php?exhibition=117 ''Ghanaian 'fantasy coffin'''], 27 September 2011 - 4 December 2011. Griff Rhys Jones. * 2010/11. [[Collection de l'art brut]], Lausanne. One-man show ''Ataa Oko et les Esprits''. * 2006 and 2007/2008. Art Museum Berne and Hygienemuseum Dresden. Exposition ''Six Feet Under: Autopsy of Our Relation to the Dead ''.
== Gallery == <gallery> File:Drawing by Ataa Oko, 2009.jpg|[[Figurative Palanquin in Ghana|Figurative palanquin]], drawing of Ataa Oko 2009 File:Drawing by Ataa Oko, 2010.jpg|Spirits, drawing of Ataa Oko 2010 File:Drawing by Ataa Oko, 2010 Football World Cup.jpg|World cup, drawing of Ataa Oko 2010 </gallery>
==Media== * 2017. [[Lucienne Peiry]], ''The Flute of Ataa Oko,'' en: Outsider Art, Vol. 3, Shanghai University Press, p. 22-33, Anglais e Chinois. {{ISBN|978-7-5671-2640-4}}/J 399. * 2017. Regula Tschumi, ''Ataa Oko. A glimpse inside the amazing world of Ghanaian funerals and how the carpenter Ataa Oko became an artist,'' online magazine Interwoven: the fabric of things. * 2014. Regula Tschumi: ''Concealed Art. The figurative palanquins and coffins of Ghana.'' Edition Till Schaap, Berne. {{ISBN|978-3-03828-099-6}}. * 2014. Regula Tschumi: ''The buried treasures of the Ga: Coffin art in Ghana.'' Edition Till Schaap, Bern. {{ISBN|9783038280163}}. A revised and updated second edition of "The buried treasures of the Ga", Bern: Benteli 2008. * 2013. Regula Tschumi "The Figurative Palanquins of the Ga. History and Significance", en: ''[[African Arts (journal)|African Arts]]'', Vol. 46, Nr. 4, 2013, pp. 60-73. * 2012/13. ''Hors-Champs.'' Ed. Musée d'Ethnographie Neuchâtel MEN. Neuchâtel: Atélier PréTexte, pp.  200–203, (français). * 2012. "Collection de l'Art Brut, Lausanne", Lucienne Peiry (ed.), Skira Flammarion 2012, pp. 26-27; 164. (français) * 2010. ''Ataa Oko''. Exhibition catalogue. ed. [[Collection de l'art brut]]. Gollion: Infolio. (français). * 2006. Regula Tschumi, "Last Respects, First Honoured. Ghanaian Burial Rituals and Figural Coffins" in: Kunstmuseum Bern (ed.), ''Six Feet Under. Autopsy of Our Relation to the Dead''. Ex.-Cat. Bielefeld, Leipzig: Kerber, pp. 114–125.
== Film, video== * 2010. [http://vimeo.com/10356159 Ataa Oko and the spirits]. Philippe Lespinasse, Regula Tschumi, Andress Alvarez. Lausanne/Le Tourne, Parti de l’Art Brut/ LoKomotiv Films, 20 minutes, (subtitled). * 2009. ''Sépulture sur mesure'', 52 minutes movie on the work of the Ga funerals, of the coffins of Ataa Oko Ado and [[Eric Adjetey Anang]] ([[Kane Kwei Carpentry Workshop]]). Philippe Lespinasse, Grand Angle Production.
== See also == *[[Art Brut]] *[[African Art]] *[[Contemporary African Art]] *[http://kvadratinterwoven.com/ataa-oko Ataa Oko. A glimpse inside the amazing world of Ghanaian funerals and how the carpenter Ataa Oko became an artist]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://regulatschumi.ch/en/artmediation/ www.regulatschumi.ch] * [https://www.artbrut.ch/fr_CH/auteurs/la-collection-de-l-art-brut/oko-ataa Ataa Oko at the Collection de l'Art Brut] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Oko, Ataa}} [[Category:Coffins]] [[Category:1919 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:Ga-Adangbe people]] [[Category:Ghanaian sculptors]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox writer | image = | imagesize = 150px | name = Cathy Scott | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = Cathleen Scott | birth_date = 1950s | birth_place = [[San Diego, California]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Writer | nationality = American | education = [[University of Redlands]] (1990)
[[Grossmont Community College]] (1970) | period = | genre = [[True crime]]
[[Creative nonfiction|Narrative nonfiction]] | subject = | movement = | notableworks = ''[[The Killing of Tupac Shakur]]''
''[[Murder of a Mafia Daughter]]'' | spouse= {{unbulleted list|Ray Somers (divorced)}} | children = Raymond Somers Jr. | relatives = [[J. Michael Scott]] (brother), [[Seraphim Rose]] (uncle), [[Esther Rose]] (grandmother)
[[Eileen Rose Busby]] and [[James (Jim) Scott]] (parents) | signature = | website = {{URL|http://www.cathyscott.com/}} }} '''Cathleen "Cathy" Scott''' (born 1950s in [[San Diego, California]]) is a ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' bestselling [[United States|American]] [[True crime|true-crime]] [[writer]] and [[investigative journalist]] best known for penning the biographies and true crime books ''[[The Killing of Tupac Shakur]]'' and ''[[The Murder of Biggie Smalls]]'', both bestsellers in the United States and United Kingdom.{{cite web|url=http://www.booksinprint.com/|title=Books In Print: Sign In|work=booksinprint.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aarons-books.co.uk/p/booklist-226.html|title=Aarons Books UK bestsellers list|author=|date=|publisher=|access-date=2007-03-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928202613/http://www.aarons-books.co.uk/p/booklist-226.html#|archive-date=2007-09-28|dead-url=yes|df=}} She grew up in [[La Mesa, California]] and later moved to [[Mission Beach, San Diego, California|Mission Beach]], California, where she was a single parent to a son, Raymond Somers Jr. Her hip-hop books are based on the drive-by shootings that killed the rappers six months apart in the midst of what has been called the [[East Coast-West Coast hip hop rivalry|West Coast-East Coast war]]. Each book is dedicated to the rappers' mothers. ==Early life and education== Scott attended [[Helix High School]] in [[La Mesa, California]], [[Grossmont Community College]] and graduated with a bachelor's degree from the [[University of Redlands]] in 1990. Scott is the daughter of the late author [[Eileen Rose Busby]],{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20050409/news_1m9busby.html|title=Eileen Rose Busby; writer, world traveler and antiques expert - The San Diego Union-Tribune|work=signonsandiego.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} and the late [[James (Jim) Scott]], a [[Senior Olympics]] winner who helped pioneer and develop the game of racquetball. She is the granddaughter of California artist [[Esther Rose]] and Frank Rose (a sports writer at the [[Two Harbors, Minnesota]], newspaper in the 1920s), and niece of the late Russian Orthodox hieromonk [[Seraphim Rose]]. Her brother is scientist and author [[J. Michael Scott]]. Her [[twin]] sister is antique store owner [[Cordelia Mendoza]]. ==Career== Scott wrote poetry as a teenager and worked on the [[Helix High School]] yearbook during her senior year. Her first full-time newspaper position was as a reporter for the ''Beach & Bay Press'' in Mission Beach and [[Pacific Beach, San Diego, California|Pacific Beach]], in 1987. She also freelanced for the ''Mira Mesa Scripps Ranch Sentinel''.{{cite web|url=http://www.manta.com/c/mtxf11g/sentinel-mira-mesa-scripps|title=Sentinel Mira Mesa Scripps, San Diego, CA|author=|date=|work=manta.com}} She then became business editor of the ''[[La Jolla]] Light'' weekly newspaper after winning a Best of Show journalism award out of 1,200 entries from the San Diego Press Club. She then moved to a daily paper, the ''Vista Press'', in North San Diego County. She left the ''Vista Press'' to string as a correspondent for the Associated Press and ''[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]]''. While reporting in San Diego, she was a member of the San Diego Press Club. In 1993, she moved to the [[Mojave Desert]] as a crime beat reporter for the ''[[Las Vegas Sun]]'', where she worked until 1998, then freelanced for ''The New York Times'' and the Reuters news service and wrote true-crime books and biographies. While still at the ''Sun'', in 1997, her first book, ''The Killing of Tupac Shakur'', was released.[http://www.streetgangs.com/topics/tupac/090497tupacbook.html Review, ''The Killing of Tupac Shakur''] Huntington Press released the book on the first anniversary of Shakur's death, issuing a 25,000-copy first printing, according to ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/print/19970825/28268-pw-on-the-trail-of-tupac.html|title=PW: On the Trail of Tupac|work=PublishersWeekly.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} with a second edition released in 2002. ''The Killing of Tupac Shakur'' was number 2 on the ''Los Angeles Times'' bestseller list in paperback nonfiction the week of June 11, 2000.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/jun/11/books/bk-39623/2|title=- Page 2 - Los Angeles Times Bestsellers|author=|date=|work=latimes}} Scott's article, first published in ''[[George (magazine)|George]]'' magazine, was included in the 2005 anthology ''[[Tupac: A Thug Life]]'', a compilation of national magazine writers released by [[Plexus Publishing]]. She contributed to two other anthologies, ''[[The Big Book of Social Media]]'' (Yorkshire Publishing 2010) and ''[[Masters of True Crime]]'' ([[Prometheus Books]] 2012). Scott has coached writers, including at the Flathead River Writers Conference in [[Montana]]{{cite web|url=http://travel.state.mt.us/categories/moreinfo.asp?IDRRecordID=12180&SiteID=1|title=Flathead River Writers Conference|author=|date=|publisher=}} and [[San Diego State University]]'s Writers' Conference.{{cite web|url=http://www.vwtapes.com/conferencepdfs/sdsu2009.pdf|title=San Diego State University's Annual Writers' Conference 2009, Faculty|author=|date=|publisher=}} Scott taught journalism and advanced magazine writing for five years at the [[University of Nevada, Las Vegas]] School of Journalism until September 2005, when she traveled to New Orleans as an embedded reporter for [[Best Friends Animal Society]] to cover animal rescues in the aftermath of [[Hurricane Katrina]] for its magazine and website. On her return from Louisiana, she hired on with Best Friends as a staff writer.{{cite web|url=http://www.cathyscott.com/about.htm|title=About Cathy Scott|work=cathyscott.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} She sat as the Nevada State Sunshine Chair for ten years, until 2007, and on the [[Society of Professional Journalists]] Sunshine Committee.{{cite web|url=http://www.lawsonline.net/Bulletin/bulletin_archives/April00/FOIA/State.htm|title=State Freedom of Information Contact Sites|author=|date=|publisher=}} From 2005 through 2007, Scott wrote a column titled "Crime & Punishment" for the [[alternative weekly]] ''[[Las Vegas CityLife]]''.[http://www.lasvegascitylife.com/shared-content/search/index.php?search=go&o=0&q=cathy+scott+crime&d1=01-06-2002&d2=03-20-2011&s=relevance&r=Subject%2CAuthor%2CContent&l=20 Article index, ''Las Vegas CityLife''] Her sixth book, ''[[Pawprints of Katrina]]: Pets Saved and Lessons Learned'', with photos by [[Clay Myers (photographer)|Clay Myers]] and foreword by actress [[Ali MacGraw]],{{cite web|url=http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-0470228512.html|title=Wiley:Pawprints of Katrina: Pets Saved and Lessons Learned|author=|date=|publisher=}} was a result of Scott's nearly four months on the [[Gulf Coast]] writing about the largest rescue of animals in U.S. history.{{cite web|url=http://network.bestfriends.org/Blogs/PostDetail.aspx?bp=1166|title=The Best Friends Blog|work=The Best Friends Blog|accessdate=6 March 2015}} Her seventh book, ''The Rough Guide to True Crime'', a title in the [[Rough Guides]] series of books,{{cite web|url=http://www.roughguides.com/website/shop/products/True-Crime.aspx|title=Rough Guides -|work=roughguides.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} was released in August 2009{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/185828385X|title=The Rough Guide to True Crime (Rough Guide Reference): Cathy Scott, Rough Guides: 9781858283852: Amazon.com: Books|work=amazon.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} and featured at [[BookExpo America]] 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/trade-shows-events/article/14565-bookexpo-america-2009-around-the-bea-booths-c-d.html|title=BookExpo America 2009: Around the BEA Booths: C - D|work=PublishersWeekly.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} She participated in the 2008 [[National Book Festival]], sponsored by the [[Library of Congress]] and hosted by First Lady [[Laura Bush]], on the National Mall in Washington, D.C.{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/bookfest/2008/authors/Scott.html|title=Participant, 2008 National Book Festival|author=|date=|publisher=}} She was a speaker at the 2011 No More Homeless Pets National Conference.{{cite web|url=http://www.cvent.com/events/2011-no-more-homeless-pets-national-conference/custom-17-b13d39015b8047a58d3a60d3a6e22ac9.aspx|title=2011 No More Homeless Pets National Conference|work=cvent.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} and at the 2012 Vegas Valley Book Festival.{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegasnevada.gov/Publications/27496.htm |title=Vegas Valley Book Festival Kicks Off Thursday (Official City of Las Vegas Web Site) |publisher=Lasvegasnevada.gov |date=2012-10-29 |accessdate=2012-11-12}} In January 2011, [[Anderson Cooper]]'s 360° blog included Scott in an update on the Tupac and [[Biggie Smalls|Smalls]] cases, quoting her as saying that "the failure to secure the actual scene of the shooting and interview witnesses immediately doomed the investigation."{{cite web|url=http://ac360.blogs.cnn.com/2011/01/06/an-ac360%C2%B0-cold-case-mystery-still-surrounds-rappers-deaths/?hpt=T2|title=An AC360° Cold Case: Mystery still surrounds rappers' deaths|work=cnn.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} Her work has appeared in ''The New York Times'', ''[[The New York Times Magazine]]'', ''[[New York Post]]'', ''[[George (magazine)|George]]'' magazine, ''Los Angeles Times'', ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]],'' ''[[U-T San Diego|San Diego Union-Tribune]]'' and ''Las Vegas Sun''. On [[KTTV]]'s "[[Good Day L.A.]]" in March 2013, Scott discussed the verdict against chef David Viens in the disappearance of his wife Dawn.{{cite web|url=http://www.myfoxla.com/story/21731396/cathy-scott-in-his-words-he-shut-her-up |title=Cathy Scott: In His Words, He Shut Her Up - Los Angeles Local News, Weather, and Traffic |publisher=Myfoxla.com |date=2013-03-20 |accessdate=2013-03-24}} Scott appeared twice on the public-access TV show ''[[Connie Martinson|Connie Martinson Talks Books]]'' in January 2003 to talk about the unsolved killing of [[Susan Berman]] and her book ''[[Murder of a Mafia Daughter]]''{{cite web|url=http://ccdl.libraries.claremont.edu/cdm4/results.php?CISOOP1=exact&CISOFIELD1=book&CISOROOT=/cmt&CISOBOX1=Murder+of+a+Mafia+daughter+%3A+the+life+and+tragic+death+of+Susan+Berman|title=Connie Martinson Talks Books|work=claremont.edu|accessdate=6 March 2015}} and in November 2000 to discuss rapper [[The Notorious B.I.G.]] and the book ''The Murder of Biggie Smalls''.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2468138/|title="Connie Martinson Talks Books" Cathy Scott 'The Murder of Biggie Smalls' (TV Episode 2000)|work=IMDb|accessdate=6 March 2015}} She appeared on three Oxygen network "[[Snapped]]" segments concerning murder cases involving women and on ''[[Unsolved Mysteries]]'' about the Tupac Shakur investigation. In 2010 she appeared in the Discovery Channel's documentary, ''[[On the Case with Paula Zahn]]: Death in the Desert'', about the Ted Binion trial.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1558060/|title="On the Case with Paula Zahn" Death in the Desert (TV Episode 2009)|work=IMDb|accessdate=6 March 2015}} On November 7 and 8, 2015, she appeared on a [[FOX News]] special about Robert Durst to discuss details about Berman's relationship with [[Robert Durst]] covered in Scott's book ''Murder of a Mafia Daughter''.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/transcript/2015/11/04/justice-with-judge-jeanine-special-robert-durst-and-my-quest-for-justice/|title='Justice with Judge Jeanine' Special: Robert Durst and My Quest For Justice|author=|date=|work=Fox News}} ''Las Vegas CityLife'' newspaper named Scott's 2003 release, ''Murder of a Mafia Daughter'', "Pick of the Week" in February of that year.{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegascitylife.com/articles/2003/02/27/city_picks/citypicks.txt|title=''Las Vegas CityLife'', "Pick of the Week: ''Murder of a Mafia Daughter''," February 27, 2003|author=|date=|publisher=}} In 2011, she wrote the introduction and foreword to military [[combat photographer]] [[Russell Klika]]'s book ''Iraq: Through the Eyes of an American Soldier''.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Iraq-Through-Eyes-American-Soldier/dp/1935758020/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1339994035&sr=1-1&keywords=klika+iraq|title=Iraq: Through the Eyes of an American Soldier: Russell Lee Klika, Cathy Scott: 9781935758020: Amazon.com: Books|work=amazon.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} Her eighth book, ''[[The Millionaire's Wife]]'', about the 1990 contract murder of businessman George Kogan,{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2010/06/04/2010-06-04_barbara_kogan_67_gets_12_years_for_ordering_hit_on_husband_20_years_ago.html|publisher=[[New York Daily News]] |title=Barbara Kogan gets 12 years for ordering hit on husband |date=June 4, 2010|author=}} was released by [[St. Martin's Press]] True Crime Library in March 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.blogtalkradio.com/crimewire/blog/2009/02|title=Inside Lenz Network|work=BlogTalkRadio|accessdate=6 March 2015}} The book was launched at Scott's former high school library in April 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2012/apr/12/book-launch-at-helix-on-friday/?print&page=all|title=Book launch at Helix on Friday|author=Karen Pearlman|work=U-T San Diego|accessdate=6 March 2015}} In 2013, ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' reported that Scott was co-writing, with former drug kingpin [["Freeway" Rick Ross]], his autobiography, released in 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/08/07/rick-ross-drug-kingpin_n_3713419.html|title=Rick Ross, Former Drug Kingpin: 'Why Wouldn't You Want To Emulate Me If You Can't Even Get a Job At McDonald's?|website=The Huffington Post|date=2013-08-07}} The memoir, ''[[Freeway Rick Ross (book)|Freeway Rick Ross: The Untold Autobiography]]'', was launched at the Eso Won Bookstore in Los Angeles on June 17, 2014, to a standing-room-only crowd.{{cite web|url=http://www.lasentinel.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=13160:rick-ross-book-signing-event-recap&catid=77:exclusive&Itemid=167|title=Rick Ross Book signing Event Recap|author=Nicole Williams|work=lasentinel.net|accessdate=6 March 2015}} In May 2014, Scott lodged a complaint with [[YouTube]] over a re-created image included in rapper [[Wyclef Jean]]'s music video "April Showers." The controversy arose after Scott reported to YouTube that no attribution had been given, nor was permission sought for use of an autopsy photo released in Scott's book ''The Killing of Tupac Shakur''. YouTube banned the video.{{cite web|url=http://www.bet.com/news/music/2014/05/08/wyclef-video-pulled-over-tupac-autopsy-image.html|title=Wyclef Video Pulled Over Tupac Autopsy Image|date=8 May 2014|work=BET.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} [[TMZ]], which broke the story, reported that video director Hezues R' and Scott had settled the matter and agreed upon a screen credit at the end of the video.{{cite web|url=http://www.tmz.com/2014/05/09/tupac-shakur-autopsy-photo-fake-wyclef-jean-music-video-settlement/|title=Tupac Shakur: Fake Autopsy Music Video Dispute SETTLED|work=tmz.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} Scott is a contributor to ''[[Psychology Today]]'',{{cite web|last=Scott |first=Cathy |url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/crime-she-writes |title=Crime, She Writes |publisher=''Psychology Today'' |date= |accessdate=2013-02-09}} [[Forbes]]Woman blog{{cite web|url=https://blogs.forbes.com/people/cathyscott/|title=Forbes » Contributor Profile » Cathy Scott|work=forbes.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} and [[Women in Crime Ink]],{{cite web|url=http://www.womenincrimeink.blogspot.com/|title=Women in Crime Ink|work=womenincrimeink.blogspot.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} described by ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' as "a blog worth reading."{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203771904574173874199242710|title=Blogs Worth Reading - WSJ|author=beckey bright|date=2 June 2009|work=WSJ|accessdate=6 March 2015}} In March 2015, her book ''[[Unconditional Honor|Unconditional Honor: Wounded Warriors and Their Dogs]]'', with photos by [[Clay Myers (photographer)|Clay Myers]] and foreword by [[Bill Walton]], was released by [[Globe Pequot Press]].{{cite web|url=http://www.coronadonewsca.com/news/coronado_home_and_business/author-to-lecture-and-sign-book-about-wounded-warriors-and/article_1885673c-ecf5-11e4-b8e1-1fb10089ad00.html|title=Author To Lecture And Sign Book About Wounded Warriors And Their Dogs|author=|date=|work=Coronado News}} In 2017, Scott co-authored ''[[The Crime Book]]'' volume with American crime writers [[Shanna Hogan]], [[Lee Mellor]], [[Rebecca Morris (author)|Rebecca Morris]] and British author Michael Kerrigan, with a foreword for the U.S. edition by Scott and the U.K. edition by author [[Peter James (writer)|Peter James]].{{cite web |url= http://www.readersdigest.co.uk/books/book-lists/best-new-books-you-should-read-april |title= Best new books you should read this April |author= |date= March 2017 |publisher= Reader's Digest}} It was released in April 2017 in the [[United Kingdom|U.K.]] and May 2017 in the [[United States|U.S.]] by [[Dorling Kindersley]] ([[Penguin Random House]]). In an August 2017 interview with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine, Scott explained the choice of stories for the book: "We tried to include the famous ones, and then some lesser-known. They needed to be from across the world and across the years and across a variety of crimes."{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/lists/crime-book-what-we-learned-from-giant-history-of-true-crime-w496295|title='The Crime Book': What We Learned from Giant History of True Crime|author=Phoebe Neidl |date=August 22, 2017|publisher=''Rolling Stone''}} ===Film=== In February 2014, filming in Las Vegas was completed for ''Death in the Desert'', a full-length movie directed and produced by [[Josh Evans (film producer)|Josh Evans]] and starring [[Michael Madsen]], [[Shayla Beesley]],[http://www.reviewjournal.com/cinspiredolumns-blogs/norm-clarke/photographer-helped-madsen-meet-sinatra Photographer helped Madsen meet Sinatra | ''Las Vegas Review-Journal''] [[Paz de la Huerta]], [[Roxy Saint]] and [[Stephen Manley]],{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3562852/fullcredits|title=Death in the Desert (2015)|author=|date=|publisher=|via=www.imdb.com}} based on Scott's book ''[[Death in the Desert]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/columns-blogs/john-l-smith/kindest-cut-all-cancer-patients|title=Kindest cut of all for cancer patients|author=John L. Smith Las Vegas Review-Journal|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|accessdate=6 March 2015}} with screenplay by [[John Steppling (playwright)|John Steppling]].{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/joanna-perryfolino/man-of-conviction_b_4886456.html|title=Man of Conviction: John Steppling -- Playwright, Screenwriter and Teacher|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=6 March 2015}} ===Awards=== *Best of Show, San Diego Press Club, 1989 *Best Spot News Story (3rd Place), [[Nevada Press Association]], 2007{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/news/nevada-press-association-2007-award-winners|title=NEVADA PRESS ASSOCIATION 2007 AWARD WINNERS|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|accessdate=6 March 2015}} *Top 10 Best True Crime Books, ''True Crime Zine'' reader's poll, 2012{{cite web|author=January 12, 2013 3:50 am |url=http://truecrimezine.com/best-true-crime-books-2012-winners/ |title=Best True Crime Books 2012 Winners List |publisher=''True Crime Zine'' |date=2013-01-04 |accessdate=2013-01-12}} *''ForeWord'' magazine's 2013 Book of the Year Awards, True Crime (finalist){{cite web|url=https://botya.forewordreviews.com/finalists/2013/all/|title=All 2013 Finalists — IndieFab Awards|work=forewordreviews.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} *''ForeWord'' magazine's silver award for 2013 Book of the Year in True Crime{{cite web|url=https://indiefab.forewordreviews.com/winners/2013/all/|title=All 2013 Winners — IndieFab Awards|work=forewordreviews.com|accessdate=6 March 2015}} * ''ForeWord'' magazine's 2014 Book of the Year Awards, True Crime (finalist){{cite web|url=https://indiefab.forewordreviews.com/finalists/2014/all/|title=All 2014 Finalists — Foreword Reviews' INDIEFAB Book of the Year Awards|author=|date=|work=forewordreviews.com}} === Published works === ==== Non-fiction ==== * ''[[The Killing of Tupac Shakur]]'' (2014, 2002, 1997, Huntington Press) ({{ISBN|1935396544}}) * ''[[The Murder of Biggie Smalls]]'' (2000, St. Martin's Press) ({{ISBN|0312266200}}) * ''[[Death in the Desert]]: The [[Ted Binion]] Homicide Case'' (2012, 2000) ({{ISBN|1588205320}}) * ''Seraphim Rose: The True Story and Private Letters'' (2000) ({{ISBN|1928653014}}) * ''Murder of a Mafia Daughter: The Life and Tragic Death of [[Susan Berman]]'' (2002, [[Barricade Books]]) ({{ISBN|1569802386}}) * ''[[Pawprints of Katrina|Pawprints of Katrina: Pets Saved and Lessons Learned]]'' (2008) ({{ISBN|0470228512}}) * ''The Rough Guide to True Crime'' (2009, [[Penguin Books|Penguin]]) ({{ISBN|185828385X}}) * ''The Millionaire's Wife'' (2012, St. Martin's Press True Crime Library) ({{ISBN|0312594356}}) * ''Murder in Beverly Hills'' (2013, AuthorHouse)'' ({{ISBN|978-1434305602}}) * ''[[Freeway Rick Ross (book)|''Freeway Rick Ross: The Untold Autobiography]]'' (co-author) (2014, Freeway Studios) ({{ISBN|978-1499651539}}) * ''Unconditional Honor: Wounded Warriors and Their Dogs'' (2015, [[Globe Pequot Press]]) ({{ISBN|978-1493003297}}) * ''Murder of a Mafia Daughter: The Story Behind Suspicions Robert Durst Murdered Susan Berman'' (2015 2nd ed, Barricade Books) ({{ISBN|978-0934878494}}) * ''[[The Crime Book]]'' (co-authored) (2017, [[Dorling Kindersley]]) ({{ISBN|978-1465462862}}) ==== Anthologies (contributor) ==== * ''Tupac: A Thug Life'' (2005, [[Plexus Publishing]]) ({{ISBN|978-0859653756}}) * ''[[The Big Book of Social Media]]: Case Studies, Stories, Perspectives'' (2010, Yorkshire Publishing) ({{ISBN|978-0881441598}}) * ''[[Masters of True Crime]]: Chilling Stories of Murder and the Macabre'' (2012, [[Prometheus Books]]) ({{ISBN|978-1616145675}}) ==Personal life== She was married to Raymond Somers, with whom she has a son, Raymond Somers Jr.{{cite book|author=Cathy Scott |title=The Millionaire's Wife|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ezdbrPNBgpcC&pg=PR8&lpg=PR8&dq=%22cathy+scott%22+author+%22raymond+somers%22&source=bl&ots=6U4V5UxtQx&sig=NSXevcjsSCljatzHm4zrqWfarKw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj7hM_2gcHbAhVErVkKHTiSBJAQ6AEIWTAL#v=onepage&q=%22cathy%20scott%22%20author%20%22raymond%20somers%22&f=false|year=2009|publisher=MacMillan|page=viii}} She lives in [[Julian, California]], a mountain town in San Diego County.{{cite web|url=https://www.thisoldhouse.com/ideas/old-miners-cabin-becomes-lesson-low-impact-living|title=An Old Miner's Cabin Becomes a Lesson in Low-Impact Living|author=|date=1 December 2016|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.coronadonewsca.com/news/coronado_home_and_business/author-to-lecture-and-sign-book-about-wounded-warriors-and/article_1885673c-ecf5-11e4-b8e1-1fb10089ad00.html|title=Author To Lecture And Sign Book About Wounded Warriors And Their Dogs|author=|date=|work=Coronado Eagle & Journal - Coronado News - Coronado Island News}} == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == * [http://www.cathyscott.com/ Cathy Scott Official Site] * [http://crimeshewrites.com/ Cathy Scott Official Blog] * [http://us.macmillan.com/author/cathyscott St. Martin's Press author bio] * [https://www.amazon.com/Cathy-Scott/e/B001HD0XQA/ref=sr_tc_ep?qid=1299411756 Amazon author page] * [http://www.authorsguild.org/?p=13319 Member, Authors Guild] * [http://cathyscott.com/pdf/wd1002.pdf Writer's Digest, Oct. 2002] * [http://www.cathyscott.com/artcls/Publisher_Defends_Shakur_Photo.html Book publisher defends Shakur photo, ''Las Vegas Sun'', Sept. 1997] * [http://www.vegasvalleybookfest.org/writers/ Vegas Valley Book Festival] * {{IMDb name|1025638}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110807131154/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/celebrity/shakur_BIG/4.html truTV Crime Library citation, "Life After Death," by Anthony Bruno for Hip Hop Homicide section] * [http://www.worldcat.org/search?q=%22Cathy+Scott%22&qt=results_page WorldCat bibliography] * [http://www.viewnews.com/2010/VIEW-Oct-19-Tue-2010/anthem/39016137.html ''View News'', "True-Crime Journalist to Speak to Writers Group," October 19, 2010] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Scott, Cathy}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American alternative journalists]] [[Category:American bloggers]] [[Category:American investigative journalists]] [[Category:American journalism academics]] [[Category:American newspaper reporters and correspondents]] [[Category:American non-fiction crime writers]] [[Category:American people of Norwegian descent]] [[Category:American people of Swedish descent]] revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{More citations needed|date=July 2016}} {{BLP primary sources|date=July 2016}} }} {{Infobox person | name = Charles Derber | birth_date = January 1944 | birth_place = [[Washington DC]] | alma_mater = [[Yale University]] | occupation = [[Professor]] of [[Sociology]] and [[:Category:American sociologists|American Political Writer]] | employer = [[Boston College]] | website = [https://sites.google.com/a/bc.edu/charles-derber/ Boston College; Google Site] }}
'''Charles Derber''' is an American Professor of [[Sociology]] at [[Boston College]].
==Early life and education== Derber was born in Washington DC in January 1944, the son of New Deal economist [[Milton Derber]]. Routine evenings in the Derber household featured dinner discussions of politics and economics, imprinting a New Deal ideological framework upon young Derber. Reaching adulthood in the 1960s, Derber buried himself within the works of [[Karl Marx]] and [[Herbert Marcuse]] while in jail for protesting the [[Vietnam War]].<ref>Slagle, N.P. "Conversations with Activists II: The Sociologist Charles Derber", Scire Populum et Potentiam[https://scirepopulumetpotentiam.info/2018/11/08/conversations-with-activists-ii-the-sociologist-charles-derber/]</ref> He attended [[Yale University]], where he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts Degree in 1965 and was a member of [[Manuscript Society]]. He attended the [[University of Chicago]], and obtained his PhD in political science.<ref name=bc>[https://www.bc.edu/bc-web/schools/mcas/departments/sociology/people/faculty-directory/charles-derber.html Charles Derber ] Boston College Faculty, accessed April 14, 2018</ref>
==Career== Derber started at Brandeis University in 1979 and switched to Boston College in 1980. He became a professor in 1991 and has been teaching in the graduate program on social economy and social justice ever since.<ref name=bc/>
Derber's work falls into three major categories. One is a critique of individualism and American culture. His 1980 book ''The Pursuit of Attention'' focuses on [[Egocentrism|ego-centeredness]] and "[[conversational narcissism]]" in everyday life as structured by class, gender and America’s individualistic culture. In 2000, Oxford University Press<ref>[http://www.oup.com/us/catalog/general/subject/Sociology/PopularCulture/?view=usa&ci=9780195135497 Oxford University Press; The Pursuit of Attention - Power and Ego in Everyday Life]</ref> printed a 20th year commemorative edition of the book, making it a classic sociological work. ''The Wilding of America'', in its fifth edition, is a widely used text in American sociology. It offers a sharp critique of the [[American Dream]] and the crisis of hyper-[[individualism]].{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}
Derber is best known to the general public for his analysis of [[Corporation|corporate]] power and globalization.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} His book ''Corporation Nation''<ref>[http://www.macmillanacademic.com/Academic/book/BookDisplay.asp?BookKey=274379 Macmillan Books; Corporation Nation - How Corporations are Taking Over Our Lives and What We Can Do About It]</ref> is an study of how corporations penetrate and control every sector of American life. ''People Before Profit'',<ref>[http://www.macmillanacademic.com/Academic/book/BookDisplay.asp?BookKey=1106348 Macmillan Books; People Before Profit - The New Globalization in an Age of Terror, Big Money, and Economic Crisis]</ref> a treatment of corporate globalization and its alternatives, has been published in five languages.
His books, ''Regime Change Begins at Home'' and ''Hidden Power'', deal with the marriage of political and economic power in America. In 2006, the Independent Publisher Book Award (IPPY) nominated ''Hidden Power''<ref>[http://www.bkpub.com/ProdDetails.asp?ID=157675345X Berrett-Koehler Publishers; Hidden Power - What You Need to Know to Save Our Democracy]</ref> as one of the three best American books on current events.
Derber's interests evolved to focus on ideology and political morality, as well as the new dynamics of global capitalism and of the movements, such as the Occupy Movement, that challenge it. His 2008 book, ''Morality Wars''<ref>[http://www.paradigmpublishers.com/books/BookDetail.aspx?productID=180319 Paradigm Publishers; Morality Wars - How Empires, the Born Again, and the Politically Correct Do Evil in the Name of Good]</ref> (co-authored with Yale Magrass), analyzes hegemonic discourses from the Roman Empire to the present. It also examines religious and "born again" ideologies, from German fascism to contemporary evangelical politics in the United States. Another 2008 book, with Katherine Adam, ''The New Feminized Majority'',<ref>[http://www.paradigmpublishers.com/Books/BookDetail.aspx?productID=180321 Paradigm Publishers; The New Feminized Majority - How Democrats Can Change America with Women's Values]</ref> examines the gendered character of values and politics in America. It shows that a new electoral majority has embraced progressive values historically associated with women; values now shared by millions of men.
In 2010, Derber published Greed to Green: Solving Climate Change and Remaking the Economy <ref>[http://www.paradigmpublishers.com/books/BookDetail.aspx?productID=180329 Paradigm Publishers;Greed to Green: Solving Climate Change and Remaking the Economy]</ref> (Paradigm Publishers, 2010), that shows that [[climate change]] is a symptom of a dysfunctional lifestyle that can be solved only through a transformation of American capitalism and [[neo-liberal]] globalization. He argues that we are seeing a third wave environmentalism that is inseparable from the broader social and economic justice movements. In 2011, he published Marx's Ghost: Midnight Conversations on Changing the World,<ref>[http://www.paradigmpublishers.com/Books/BookDetail.aspx?productID=180333 Paradigm Publishers; Marx's Ghost: Midnight Conversations on Changing the World]</ref> also translated also into Korean and Chinese. In an imaginative encounter, Derber engages Marx's ghost in a provocative conversation about today's crises, relying extensively on Marx's own quotations. Turning to a genre of literary social science, based on conversation, Derber lays out alternative visions and political strategies for movements such as the [[Occupy Movement]].
Derber's 2012 book ''The Surplus American: How the 1% Is Making Us Redundant'',<ref>[http://www.paradigmpublishers.com/Books/BookDetail.aspx?productID=321345 Paradigm Publishers; The Surplus American: How the 1% Is Making Us Redundant]</ref> co-authored with Yale Magrass, continues Derber's evolution into new genres of political writing. The Surplus American features not only a careful analysis of "surplus people," those without jobs or any meaningful place in society, but a concluding play already performed at [[Boston College]]. The book describes a [[dystopia]] in 2020, where the majority of Americans have been rendered redundant through [[outsourcing]], technological change and a corporate strategy to abandon the entire US economic infrastructure. While first drafted before the rise of the Occupy Movement the analysis is, prophetically, structured around a confrontation on Wall Street between financial elites and surplus people protesters.
Derber’s 2017 book is ''Welcome to the Revolution: Universalizing Resistance for Social Justice''.<ref>[https://www.routledge.com/Welcome-to-the-Revolution-Universalizing-Resistance-for-Social-Justice/Derber/p/book/9781138648203 Routledge; Welcome to the Revolution: Universalizing Resistance for Social Justice]</ref> It explores the anti-Trump resistance movement and the anti-systemic universalizing movement needed to transform contemporary militarized capitalism. In conjunction with that book, Derber has brought together leaders of unions and many social justice movement, to analyze where we go from here. With Routledge Publishers, Derber is editing a new Universalizing Resistance Book Series where leading critical public intellectuals and activists analyze and flesh out stories of mass anti-systemic resistance that moves beyond the siloes of our current Left and Progressive movements. Derber is also helping direct a series of films and books about and with Noam Chomsky, funded by the Wallace Action Fund.
Derber is known as a [[public sociologist]] who writes for general audiences, offering not only sociological critiques but alternative visions. He appears frequently on talk shows, has written opinion pieces for media including the International Herald Tribune, the Boston Globe, the Christian Science Monitor, Newsday and [[Tikkun (magazine)|Tikkun]], and is a regular contributor to ''Cognoscenti'', the opinion page of [[WBUR]], Boston's NPR station.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} He is one of the most prominent contemporaries of the sociological imagination{{according to whom|date=April 2018}} as championed by [[C. Wright Mills]], and, like Mills, he believes in the importance of melding critical scholarship with social justice activism.
==Personal life== Derber has long been active in the peace, environmental and labor movements, from his 1960s work to register African-American voters in the [[Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party]] and his opposition to the Vietnam War to current movements such as Occupy and the struggle to prevent climate change and transform global [[corporate capitalism]] into a robust economic and political democracy.{{according to whom|date=April 2018}}
==Works== Derber’s work focuses on the crises of capitalism, globalization, corporate power, American militarism, the culture of hegemony, the climate crisis, and the new peace and global justice movements. Derber is persuaded that the overwhelming economic and cultural power of global corporations, increasingly melded with the political and military hegemonic power of the American government and the crises of global capitalism and global climate change, are together an integrated crisis that is now the pre-eminent social issue of the 21st century, and that a new vision and political movement is needed. Derber’s research is oriented toward 1) the systemic analysis of the intertwined crises we face and 2) analysis of the transformative potential of social movements arising to create a more democratic and egalitarian order. His works include: * {{cite book <!--|last=Derber |first=Charles |authorlink=Charles Derber--> |title=Welcome to the Revolution: Universalizing Resistance for Social Justice and Democracy in Perilous Times |url=http://www.routledge.com/Welcome-to-the-Revolution-Universalizing-Resistance-for-Social-Justice/Derber/p/book/9781138648203 |year=2017 |publisher=[[Routledge]] |isbn= 978-1138648203 }} * |year=2014 |publisher=[[Routledge]] |isbn= 978-1612056890 }} * {{cite book <!--|last=Derber |first=Charles |authorlink=Charles Derber--> |title=Sociopathic Society: A People's Sociology of the United Derber |last2=Magrass |first2=Yale R -->|title=Surplus American: How the 1% is Making Us Redundant |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IgnvCgAAQBAJ |date=17 November 2015 |orig-year=1st pub. 2012 the Born Again, and the Politically Correct Do Evil in the Name of Good,"Paradigm, 2010) *''The Wilding of America: Money, Mayhem, and the New American Dream'' (Worth Publishers, 5th edition 2009) {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = Chavela Vargas | image = Chavela Vargas y La Banda de Tlayacapan..jpg | caption = Chavela Vargas in 2009 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Isabel Vargas Lizano | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1919|4|17}} | birth_place = [[San Joaquín de Flores]], [[Heredia Province]], [[Costa Rica]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2012|8|5|1919|4|17}} | death_place = [[Cuernavaca]], [[Morelos]], [[Mexico]] | genre = [[Ranchera]] | occupation = [[Singer–songwriter]], [[actress]] | years_active = 1961– 2012 | associated_acts = [[José Alfredo Jiménez]] | website ]}}
{{Spanish name|Vargas|Lizano}}
'''Isabel Vargas Lizano''' ({{IPA-es|tʃaˈβel ˈβaɾɣas}}; 17 April 1919 – 5 August 2012), better known as '''Chavela Vargas''', was a Costa Rican-born Mexican singer. She was especially known for her rendition of Mexican [[ranchera]]s, but she is also recognized for her contribution to other genres of popular Latin American music. She has been an influential interpreter in the Americas and Europe, muse to figures such as [[Pedro Almodóvar]], hailed for her haunting performances, and called "la voz áspera de la ternura", the rough voice of tenderness.<ref name="Boccanera, Jorge 1999">Boccanera, Jorge, Entrelineas: Dialogos con Jorge Boccanera, ed. Mario José Grabivker (Buenos Aires: Ediciones instituto movilizador fondos cooperativos C.L., 1999)</ref> The Latin Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences, presented her with a Latin GRAMMY Statuette in 2007 after receiving a Lifetime Achievement Award on behalf of that organization.
==Early life and career== [[File:Chavela Vargas 060701.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Vargas during a concert in Spain, 2006.]] She was born in [[Costa Rica]], in [[San Joaquín de Flores]], as Isabel Vargas Lizano, daughter of Francisco Vargas and Herminia Lizano. She was baptized on 15 July 1919 with the forenames "María Isabel Anita Carmen de Jesús." She had a difficult childhood: her parents divorced and left her under the care of an uncle, and she contracted poliomyelitis. She went by ''Chavela'', which is a [[Hypocorism|pet name]] for Isabel. At age 17,<ref>Vargas, Chavela, ''Y si quieres saber de mi pasado'', ed. J.C. Vales, 2nd ed (Madrid: Santillana Ediciones Generales, 2002). In the interview with Jorge Boccanera, Vargas is quoted as saying she arrived in Mexico at 17.</ref> she abandoned her native country due to lack of opportunities for a musical career, seeking refuge in Mexico, where an entertainment industry was burgeoning. There she resided for almost eight decades and obtained Mexican nationality. {{Citation needed|date=August 2013}}
For many years she [[street performance|sang on the streets]], but in her thirties she became a professional singer.<ref>{{cite news|last=Garrido|first=Isaac|title=Chavela Vargas Dead At Age 93, Famed Mexican Singer Challenged Catholic And Chauvinist Preconceptions|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/05/chavela-vargas-dead-age-93_n_1744910.html|accessdate=5 August 2012|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=5 August 2012}}</ref> In her youth, she dressed as a man, smoked cigars, drank heavily, carried a gun, and was known for her characteristic red [[poncho|jorongo]], which she donned in performances until old. Vargas sang the [[ranchera|canción ranchera]], which she performed in her own peculiar style. The typical ranchera, as represented by [[José Alfredo Jiménez]], was a masculine but emotional song about love and its mishaps, usually mediated by alcohol, since in a [[macho]] culture, the display of feelings by men is allowed only to the drunk. The ranchera is sung from a man's perspective and with a mariachi accompaniment. Chavela sang this type of song as a solo, using only guitar and voice, evoking the singing style of a drunk man. She often slowed down the tempo of melodies to draw more dramatic tension out of songs, so they could be taken as naughtily humorous.
Towards the end of the 1950s, she became known within artistic circles, due in part to her performances in Acapulco, center of international tourism, where she sang at the Champagne Room of the restaurant La Perla. Her first album, ''Noche de Bohemia'' (Bohemian Night), was released in 1961 with the professional support of [[José Alfredo Jiménez]], one of the foremost singer/songwriters of Mexican ranchera music.<ref>''Diccionario de la Música Española e Hispanoamericana.'' 5 vols. Madrid: Sociedad General de Autores y Editores, 2002. s.v. "Vargas, Chavela".</ref> She eventually recorded more than 80 albums.<ref>Yarbro-Bejarano, Yvonne. "Crossing the Border with Chabela Vargas: A Chicana Femme's Tribute" [sic] Chap. 3, ''Sex and Sexuality in Latin America'' (New York: New York University Press, 1997)<!-- isbn needed --></ref> Vargas was hugely successful during the 1950s, the 1960s, and the first half of the 1970s, touring in Mexico, the United States, France, and Spain<ref>Diccionario de la Música Española e Hispanoamericano. 5 vols. Madrid: Sociedad General de Autores y Editores, 2002.</ref> and was close to many prominent artists and intellectuals of the time, including [[Juan Rulfo]], [[Agustín Lara]], [[Frida Kahlo]], [[Diego Rivera]], [[Dolores Olmedo]] and [[José Alfredo Jiménez]].<ref name="Boccanera, Jorge 1999"/>
==Partial retirement and return to the stage==
In the late 1970s Vargas partially retired from performing due to a 15-year battle with alcoholism, which she described in her autobiography (''Y si quieres saber de mi pasado'' [And if you want to know about my past], published in 2002) as "my 15 years in hell."<ref>Vargas, Chavela, ''Y si quieres saber de mi pasado'', ed. J.C. Vales, 2nd ed (Madrid: Santillana Ediciones Generales, 2002), p. 189</ref> Chavela couldn't keep on with her heavy drinking and intense lifestyle. In 1970, "submerged in an alcoholic haze" as she described it, she was taken in by an [[Indigenous peoples of Mexico|Indian]] family who nursed her back to health without knowing who she was. In 2003, she told ''The New York Times'' that she had not had a drink in 25 years.<ref name="nytimes.com">[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/07/arts/music/chavela-vargas-mexican-ranchera-singer-dies-at-93.html?_r=0 Obituary in the ''New York Times''], 7 August 2012</ref>
Vargas returned to the stage in 1991, performing at a bohemian nightclub called "El Hábito" in Coyoacán, Mexico City.<ref name="Boccanera, Jorge 1999"/> Her career started to recover international prominence, with performances in Latin America, Europe and the United States.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> Vargas debuted at [[Carnegie Hall]] in 2003 at age 83<ref>Vargas, Chavela. (2006) Chavela at Carnegie Hall, CD recording, Tommy Boy</ref> at the behest and promotion of Spanish director [[Pedro Almodóvar]], an admirer and friend.
At age 81, she publicly [[Coming out|came out]] as a lesbian in her autobiography titled ''And If You Want to Know about My Past''.
But it wasn't really a surprise to her fans. For years Vargas refused to change the genders in her songs. In "Paloma Negra" ("Black Dove"), Vargas accuses a woman of partying all night long and breaking her heart.
==Appearances in film== Vargas is featured in many of Almodóvar's films, including ''[[The Flower of My Secret|La flor de mi secreto]]'' in both song and video. She said, however, that acting was not her ambition, although she had previously participated in films such as the 1967 movie ''La Soldadera.''<ref name="Boccanera, Jorge 1999"/> Vargas also appeared in ''[[Frida]]'', singing "[[La Llorona (song)|La Llorona]]" (The Weeping Woman).<ref name="Vargas, Chavela 2002">Vargas, Chavela, Y si quieres saber de mi pasado, ed. J.C. Vales, 2nd ed (Madrid: Santillana Ediciones Generales, 2002)</ref> Her classic "Paloma Negra" (Black Dove) was also included in the soundtrack of the film. Vargas herself, as a young woman, was alleged to have had an affair with Frida Kahlo during Kahlo's marriage to [[mural]]ist Diego Rivera.<ref>Sofía Ruiz-Alfaro PhD (2012) From Chavela to Frida: Loving from the Margins,Journal of Homosexuality, 59:8, 1131-1144, DOI: 10.1080/00918369.2012.712818</ref><ref name="Vargas, Chavela 2002"/> She appeared in [[Alejandro González Iñárritu]]'s ''[[Babel (film)|Babel]]'', singing "Tú me acostumbraste" ("I got used to you"),<ref>[http://odeo.com/show/6748053/view Tu Me Acostumbraste - Chavela Vargas on Odeo]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> a bolero by [[Frank Domínguez]].
On February 10, 2017, the biographical film ''Chavela'' debuted. Directed by [[Catherine Gund]] and [[Daresha Kyi]], the film features [[Pedro Almodóvar]], [[Elena Benarroch]] and [[Miguel Bosé]] among others.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6217664/ ''Chavela'' on IMDB]</ref>
==References in literature and music== [[Joaquín Sabina]]'s song "Por el Boulevard de los Sueños Rotos" ("Down the Boulevard of Broken Dreams") is dedicated to Vargas.<ref name="Boccanera, Jorge 1999"/> [[Sergio Ramírez Mercado]], a Nicaraguan writer, published in 2011 the novel ''La Fugitiva'', a fictionalized account of the life of Costa Rican writer [[Yolanda Oreamuno]]. In Ramírez' work, Oreamuno's life is told by three women who met her. According to many critics, one of the female characters telling Oreamuno's history is a singer who resembles Chavela Vargas. The character talks about her own life and her non-reciprocated lesbian love for Yolanda Oreamuno.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sergio Ramírez: política y ficción|url=http://www.sigueleyendo.es/sergio-ramirez-politica-y-ficcion/|publisher=Sigueleyendo|language=Spanish|date=April 8, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110411164803/http://www.sigueleyendo.es/sergio-ramirez-politica-y-ficcion/|archivedate=April 11, 2011|df=}}</ref>
==Death== Chavela Vargas had been hospitalized for several weeks as a result of respiratory problems. She died in Cuernavaca, Mexico. According her official Facebook page, her last words were "I leave with Mexico in my heart."
==Selected discography== *''Con el cuarteto Lara Foster'', 1961 *''Hacia la vida'', 1966 *''Corridos de la revolución'', 1970 *''Amanecí en tus brazos'', 1973 *''La Original'', 1973 *''Lamento Borincano'', 1973 *''Poema 20'', 1975 *''Noche Bohemia'', 1989 *''Noche de Ronda'', 1989 *''Piensa en mí'' AKA ''Vuelve'', 1991 *''Boleros'', 1991 *''La Llorona'', 1993 *''Sentimiento de México'' (vol. 1), 1995 *''De México y del Mundo'', 1995 *''Le canta a México'', 1995 *''Volver, volver'', 1996 *''Dos'', 1996 *''Grandes mementos'', 1996 *''Macorina'', 1994/1996 *''Chavela Vargas'', 1997 *''Pasión bolero'', 1999 *''Colección de oro'', 1999 *''Con la rondalla del amor de Saltillo'', 2000 *''Para perder la cabeza'', 2000 *''Las 15 grandes de Chavela Vargas'', 2000 *''Grandes éxitos'', 2002 *''Para toda la vida'', 2002 *''Discografía básica'', 2002 *''Antología'', 2004 *''Somos'', 2004 *''En Carnegie Hall'', 2004 *''La Llorona'', 2004 *''Cupaima'', 2006/2007 *''Soledad'', 2007 *''Piensa en mí'', on Splendor in the Grass by [[Pink Martini]], 2009 *''Luz de Luna'', on San Patricio by [[The Chieftains]] featuring Ry Cooder, 2010 *''Por mi culpa!'', 2010 *''Luna Grande'', 2012

{{short description|character in Henry IV, Part 2}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox character | name = Doll Tearsheet | series = [[Henriad]] | image = Greutzner Doll Tearsheet.jpg | caption = Doll Tearsheet with Falstaff, detail of a painting by [[Eduard von Grützner]] | first = Henry IV, Part 2 | creator = [[William Shakespeare]] | portrayer = | nickname = | alias = | species = | gender = Female | occupation = Prostitute | religion = Christian | nationality = English }} '''Doll Tearsheet''' is a fictional character who appears in Shakespeare's play ''[[Henry IV, Part 2]]''. She is a prostitute who frequents the [[Boar's Head Inn]] in Eastcheap. Doll is close friends with [[Mistress Quickly]], the proprietor of the tavern, who procures her services for [[Falstaff]].
Doll is noted for her wide repertoire of colourful insults and her sudden switches from wild tirades to sentimental intimacy and back again.
==In the play== Doll is introduced by name when [[Mistress Quickly]] asks [[Falstaff]] whether he would like her company that evening. The Page later mentions to [[Prince Hal]] and [[Poins]] that Falstaff will be seeing her, primly referring to her as "a proper gentlewoman, sir, and a kinswoman of my master's", though Hal quickly concludes that she is probably "some road" (meaning a whore: accessible to anyone, as in the phrase "as common as the cart-way").<ref name = "ren"/>
Doll is first seen about to be sick after drinking too much "[[Sack (wine)|canaries]]" (fortified wine from the Canary islands). When Falstaff arrives they exchange lewd banter about [[venereal disease]]. Informed that [[Ancient Pistol]] is at the door, Doll insists that he should not be allowed in because he's "the foul-mouthed'st rogue in England." After Pistol enters, Doll berates him with a string of insults: "I scorn you, scurvy companion. What! you poor, base, rascally, cheating, lack-linen mate! Away, you mouldy rogue, away!" She then threatens him with a knife, and Pistol pulls his sword. In the ensuing fight, Falstaff and [[Bardolph (Shakespeare character)|Bardolph]] force him out.
After his display of fighting prowess, Doll becomes very solicitous to Falstaff, calling him a "whoreson little valiant villain". She sits on his knee and kisses him. She asks him what Prince Hal is like; Falstaff gives a rather unflattering picture of him, unaware that Hal and Poins are nearby. When they reveal themselves, Falstaff claims he was intentionally "dispraising" the prince in the presence of "the wicked". Hal professes to be shocked, describing Doll as a "virtuous gentlewoman", to the enthusiastic agreement of Mistress Quickly. But Falstaff says Doll is "in hell already, and burns poor souls" (a reference to the burning sensation of venereal disease).<ref>René Weis (ed), ''Henry IV, Part 2'': Oxford University Press, 1997, p.187.</ref> When Falstaff is called away to the war, Doll becomes tearful. He leaves, but then calls on her to join him.
[[File:Doll Tearsheet being arrested.jpg|thumb|The seemingly pregnant Doll being arrested. Engraving by Richard Rhodes]] She next appears, apparently heavily pregnant, with Mistress Quickly. They are being arrested because Pistol has beaten up a man in a brawl in which they were involved. The man has since died. The officer says she will probably be whipped. Doll says that she should not be manhandled because she might have a miscarriage, but the arresting officer insists she has stuffed a cushion up her dress. Doll unleashes a stream of insults directed at the arresting officer's skinniness.
After the death of [[Henry IV of England|King Henry IV]], Falstaff learns about Doll's arrest and promises to have her released. But Hal, now king, refuses to listen to him.
==References in ''Henry V''== Though she does not appear in ''[[Henry V (play)|Henry V]]'', Doll is mentioned several times, though in contexts which appear to be inconsistent with one another. Pistol marries Mistress Quickly, whose first name is Nell. He gets into an argument with [[Corporal Nym]], who himself wanted to marry her, and tells Nym to go to the hospital ('spital) and find Doll in the ward for sexually transmitted diseases ("the powdering tub of infamy") and marry her: "Fetch forth the lazar kite of Cressid's kind,/ Doll Tearsheet she by name, and her espouse". After the [[Battle of Agincourt]] he receives a letter, from which he learns that "my Doll is dead in the 'spital" from "malady of France", i.e. [[syphilis]]. It is unclear whether this refers to Doll Tearsheet or Mistress Quickly, since the next line says he has lost his home, implying that the woman referred to is the person he lives with. It is often amended to "Nell" in modern editions. The Quarto version says "Doll is sick", not "dead", leaves out the "my", and makes no reference to losing a home.<ref name = "doc">Andrew Griffin, ''Locating the Queen's Men, 1583–1603'', Ashgate, 2013, p.142</ref>
It has been suggested that a version of ''Henry V'' existed in which Falstaff appeared, perhaps married to Quickly (which he said he would do in ''Henry IV, Part 2'').<ref name = "doc"/> At the epilogue to ''Henry IV, Part 2'' Shakespeare had promised another play to "continue the story, with Sir John in it", but Falstaff does not appear in existing versions of ''Henry V''. If such a version existed Pistol may have married Doll. If this highly speculative hypothesis is true, when Falstaff was cut out, much of his part was reassigned to Pistol, but the passage apparently referring to Doll as his wife was accidentally left unchanged.<ref name = "doc"/>
==Character== [[File:Fuseli Henry IV part 2 act II scene 4.jpg|thumb|Falstaff with Doll Tearsheet, print after [[Henry Fuseli]]]] Doll's name is obviously emblematic of her trade. A contraction of [[Dorothy (given name)|Dorothy]], the name "Doll", with its connotation of "plaything", was often given to prostitute characters, as with Doll Common in Jonson's play ''[[The Alchemist (play)|The Alchemist]]''.<ref name = "dict">Alison Findlay, "Dorothy" and "Jane", ''Women in Shakespeare: A Dictionary'', A&C Black, 2014.</ref> Her surname is suggestive of her activities, as is that of the other "loose woman" mentioned in the play, Jane Nightwork.<ref name = "dict"/> [[Stanley Wells]] and [[Eric Partridge]] say she is "so called, either because she tore the bed-sheets in her amorous tossings or because her partners did so while consorting with her".<ref>Stanley Wells & Eric Partridge, ''Shakespeare's Bawdy'', Routledge, p.258.</ref> According to René Weis, {{quote|"Tearsheet' has been read as a misprint for 'Tearstreet' (i.e. street-walker) in the light of Hal's anticipating to meet 'some road' ( 2. 2.158), but a 'sheet-walker' or 'tearer' is equally plausible, in view particularly of Beaumont and Fletcher Valentinian 3. 1.340-1, where Maximus says 'If my wife for all this should be a whore now, / A kind of kicker out of sheets'"<ref name = "ren">René Weis (ed) ''Henry IV, Part 2'', Oxford University Press, 1997, p.158, 166.</ref>}}
[[Harold Bloom]] says that Doll's eccentric compliments to Falstaff ("thou whoreson little tidy Bartholomew boar-pig") complement Hal's own apparently affectionate insults, with the difference that Doll's are sincere, since "Falstaff the Bartholomew boar-pig has just proved himself to his doxy as being, in her words, a 'whoreson little valiant villain', and is fully to her taste. Falstaff the Manningtree ox, however, has just been unmercifully made game of by the Prince for running away at Gadshill in a fashion that could only, by everyone in the tavern company except Falstaff, be taken as showing downright cowardice."<ref>Harold Bloom, ''Falstaff'', Chelsea House, 1992, p.158.</ref>
==In other literature== Doll appears along with Falstaff's other cronies in the play ''[[Falstaff's Wedding]]'' (1766), a comedy by [[William Kenrick (writer)|William Kenrick]], which is set in the period between the end of ''Henry IV, Part 2'' and the beginning of ''Henry V''. Doll and Mistress Quickly, having bribed their way out of prison, appear in the first act explaining to Falstaff how they were arrested. They later plot to disguise themselves as gentlewomen to find rich husbands, targeting [[Robert Shallow]] and Abraham Slender. Quickly intends to marry Shallow, and Doll to marry Slender. The plan appears to succeed, but Shallow and Slender find out their true identities and switch places at the weddings with Ancient Pistol and Corporal Nym, so Doll ends up married to Nym.
[[James White (1775–1820)|James White]]'s book ''Falstaff's Letters'' (1796) purports to be a collection of letters written by Falstaff and his cronies, provided by a descendant of Mistress Quickly's sister. Several letters from Quickly to Falstaff complain about his treatment of Doll.<ref>White, James, ''Falsteff's Letters'', London, Robson, 1877, p.39.</ref>
In [[Oliver St. John Gogarty]]'s poem "Applied Poetry" Doll is invoked. The poet tells his beloved that she is filled with the beauties of springtime, and like the breeze that sways a field of buttercups, "As if Doll Tearsheet lay / And leapt again". When she expresses outrage at being compared to a whore, he explains, <poem> But she was meant to show, (If Will gave lessons) That only women know The human essence, And see beneath a part, Though clothed upon By Evil, the rich heart Of gross Sir John; Which no one else perceived.<ref>Oliver St. John Gogarty, ''Selected Poems'', The Macmillan Company, 1933, p.135</ref> </poem>
Doll also appears as a character in [[Gustav Holst]]'s 1925 opera ''[[At the Boar's Head]]''. A soprano role, it was first performed by Constance Willis, conducted by [[Malcolm Sargent]].<ref>[[Margaret Ross Griffel]], Adrienne Fried Block, ''Operas in English: A Dictionary'', Greenwood Press, Westport, 1999, p.37.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Henriad}}
