{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox astronaut | name = Lisa Nowak | image = Lisa M. Nowak.jpg | type = [[NASA]] Astronaut | status = Dismissed | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1963|5|10}} | birth_place = [[Washington, D.C.]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | previous_occupation = [[Test pilot|Test Naval Flight Officer]] | alma_mater = [[United States Naval Academy]], B.S. [[aeronautical engineering]] 1985
[[Naval Postgraduate School]], M.S. 1992 | rank = [[Commander (United States)|Commander]], [[United States Navy|USN]], Retired | selection = [[NASA Astronaut Group 16|1996 NASA Group]] | space_time = 12d 18h 36min | missions = [[STS-121]] | insignia = [[File:STS-121 patch.svg|30px]] }} '''Lisa Marie Nowak''' (née '''Caputo''', born May 10, 1963) is an American former [[Naval Flight Officer|naval flight officer]] and [[NASA]] astronaut. Born in [[Washington, D.C.]], she was selected by NASA in 1996 and qualified as a [[mission specialist]] in [[robotics]]. Nowak flew aboard {{OV|103}} during the [[STS-121]] mission in July 2006, where she was responsible for operating the [[Canadarm|robotic arms]] of the shuttle and the [[International Space Station]]. On February 5, 2007, she was arrested in [[Orlando, Florida]], and subsequently charged with the attempted kidnapping of [[U.S. Air Force]] [[Captain (United States)|Captain]] Colleen Shipman, who was romantically involved with astronaut [[William Oefelein]]. Nowak was released on bail, and initially pleaded not guilty to the charges, which included attempted kidnapping, burglary with assault, and battery. Her assignment to the space agency as an astronaut was terminated by NASA effective March 8, 2007. On November 10, 2009, Nowak agreed to a [[Plea bargain|plea deal]] with prosecutors and pleaded guilty to charges of felony burglary of a car and misdemeanor battery. Nowak remained a Navy [[Captain (naval)|captain]] until August 2010, when a [[naval board of inquiry]], composed of three admirals, voted unanimously to [[Reduction in rank|reduce Nowak in rank]] to [[Commander (United States)|commander]] and to discharge her from the Navy under [[Military discharge#Other Than Honorable (OTH)|other than honorable conditions]].{{Cite news |url=http://www.navytimes.com/news/2010/08/gan-nowak-discharged-082010/ |title=Navy to discharge ex-astronaut in stalking case |agency=[[Gannet]] |newspaper=[[Navy Times]] |date=August 20, 2010 |location=[[Jacksonville, Florida]]}} ==Early life and education== Lisa Nowak is the daughter of Alfredo and Jane Caputo of [[Rockville, Maryland]]. In 1969, as a six-year-old watching the [[List of Apollo missions|Apollo]] [[moon landing]]s, Nowak first became interested in the [[space program]]. While growing up, she continued to follow the [[Space Shuttle program]], particularly the introduction of female astronauts. In 1981, Nowak graduated from [[Charles W. Woodward High School]] in Rockville, Maryland. In 1985, Nowak received her [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[aerospace engineering]] from the [[United States Naval Academy]]. In 1992, Nowak earned both a [[Master of Science]] degree in [[aeronautical engineering]] and a degree in aeronautical and [[astronautical engineering]] from the U.S. [[Naval Postgraduate School]] in [[Monterey, California]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/nowak.html |title=Astronaut Bio: Lisa M. Nowak (03/2007) |publisher=NASA |date=2007-03-01 |author = NASA |quote = Nowak returned to navy duty effective March 8, 2007. |accessdate=2007-02-06}} ==Military career== In 1985, Nowak received her commission in the [[United States Navy]]. In 1987, Nowak became a [[Naval Flight Officer]] via the Tactical Navigation syllabus at Training Squadron 86 ([[VT-86]]) at [[NAS Pensacola]], [[Florida]]. Nowak was then assigned to Electronic Warfare Aggressor Squadron 34 ([[VAQ-34]]) at [[NAS Point Mugu]], [[California]], where she flew both the [[LTV A-7 Corsair II|EA-7L]] and [[Douglas A-3 Skywarrior|ERA-3B]] aircraft, supporting the [[United States Pacific Fleet|U.S. Pacific Fleet]] in small and large-scale exercises with [[electronic warfare|jamming]] and missile profiles. In 1993, Nowak was selected for transfer to the [[Restricted Line Officer|Restricted Line]] as an Aerospace Engineering Duty Officer, and to attend the [[United States Naval Test Pilot School|U.S. Naval Test Pilot School]] at [[NAS Patuxent River]], [[Maryland]]. After graduating from the Naval Postgraduate School, Nowak stayed at Patuxent River working as an aircraft systems project officer at the Air Combat Environment Test and Evaluation Facility and at Strike Aircraft Test Squadron, flying in the [[F/A-18 Hornet|F/A-18]] and [[EA-6B Prowler|EA-6B]]. She was then assigned to the [[Naval Air Systems Command]], working on acquisition of new systems for naval aircraft, when she was selected for the astronaut program. Nowak logged over 1,500 hours of flight in over 30 different aircraft during her career in the Navy. While in the Navy, Nowak was awarded{{when|date=June 2018}} the [[Defense Meritorious Service Medal]], the [[Navy Commendation Medal]], the [[Navy Achievement Medal]], and other service awards. On 20 August 2010, after a review of the circumstances of the legal case, a panel of three U.S. Navy admirals recommended that she be discharged from the Navy and her rank reduced from Captain to Commander. Her service was classified as "other than honorable".Staff (2011-07-28). "Navy OKs ex-astronaut Nowak's retirement". ''[[Military Times]]'', 28 July 2011. Originally retrieved from http://www.navytimes.com/news/2011/07/navy-nowak-astronaut-punishment-072811w/. Archived on 2012-09-05 at http://archive.li/3WhS. ==NASA career== [[File:Lisa Nowak.jpg|thumb|Lisa Nowak during astronaut training in 2005.]] Nowak was selected to be an astronaut in 1996 and entered the [[NASA Astronaut Corps]] at [[Johnson Space Center]] in August of that year. She qualified as a mission specialist in robotics, and was assigned to a future mission designated [[STS-118]]. After schedule changes, she instead went into space on July 4, 2006, as a member of the [[STS-121]] crew assigned to the [[International Space Station]]. Nowak served as mission flight engineer, operated the Shuttle's robotic arm during several [[spacewalks]], and logged almost 13 days in space. For her work as a member of the crew of STS-118, Nowak was awarded the [[NASA Space Flight Medal]] at Johnson Space Center on June 5, 2007.{{Cite web |url=http://www.spaceref.com/news/viewpr.html?pid=22730 |title=2007 NASA Honor Awards Ceremony at JSC |date=May 30, 2007 |accessdate=November 10, 2009 |publisher=SpaceRef.com |author=NASA Johnson Space Center}} On February 6, 2007, following an arrest in Florida for attempted kidnapping, Nowak was placed on 30-day leave by NASA.{{Cite press release |url=http://www.nasa.gov/home/hqnews/2007/mar/HQ_07026_Nowak_Status.html |title=Statement Regarding the Status of Lisa Nowak |publisher=NASA |date=March 7, 2007 |accessdate=March 7, 2007}} She returned to [[Houston]], Texas, on a commercial airline flight the next day and upon arrival was reportedly taken immediately under police escort to the Johnson Space Center for medical and psychiatric evaluation. Nowak's assignment to NASA as a serving Navy officer was terminated by the space agency on March 7, 2007.{{Cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17502655/ |title=NASA fires astronaut Lisa Nowak |accessdate=January 21, 2008 |publisher=MSNBC |year=2007 |author=MSNBC}}{{Cite news |last=Stone |first=Andrea |title=In Houston, concern for Nowak—and little affection for reporters |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2007-02-07-astronaut-houston_x.htm |publisher=USA Today |date=March 7, 2007 |accessdate=March 9, 2007}} ==After NASA== Nowak remained on active duty with the Navy and was subsequently ordered to work on the staff of the chief of Naval Air Training at [[Naval Air Station Corpus Christi]], Texas. There, she was involved in the development of flight training curricula for broad use throughout the Navy.{{Cite news|last=Doukopil |first=Tony |title=Lisa Nowak's Strange Spacewalk |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/19695788/site/newsweek/ |publisher=Newsweek |date=2007-07-10 |accessdate=2007-07-17 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070713230924/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/19695788/site/newsweek/ |archivedate=2007-07-13 |deadurl=yes }} Naval officials waited for her kidnapping case to be resolved before taking further action against her.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/08/science/space/08astronaut.html?ex=1331010000&en=bc9edf1400e47963&ei=5088&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss |title=NASA Fires Arrested Astronaut |author=[[The New York Times]] |publisher=The New York Times |date=2007-03-08 |accessdate=2008-01-21}} Military law experts have stated that, while the Navy rarely brings charges against officers for adultery, it is seen as [[Conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman|conduct unbecoming an officer]], as it demonstrates bad judgment.{{Cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2007-03-06-astronaut-nowak_N.htm |title=E-mails offer clues to astronauts' triangle |accessdate=2008-01-21 |publisher=USA Today |author=Traci Watson |date=2007-03-06}} Nowak's state of mind during the incident was the subject of a play, ''Starcrosser's Cut'', which opened in Los Angeles in June 2013.{{cite news |last=Harbaugh |first=Pam |title=Disgraced astronaut Nowak subject of new play |url=http://www.floridatoday.com/article/20130606/COLUMNISTS0105/306060063/Disgraced-astronaut-Nowak-subject-new-play |accessdate=2013-06-06 |newspaper=Florida Today |date=2013-06-06}} In 2017, at the age of 54, Nowak was reported to be living in Texas and working in the "private sector". Her attorney stated: "She's doing well."Helling, Steve (2017-10-24). Astronaut Love Triangle: Lisa Nowak's Life 10 Years Later. Crime, People, 24 October 2017. Retrieved on 2018-06-04 from https://people.com/crime/astronaut-love-triangle-lisa-nowak-life-10-years-later/. In 2018, pre-production began on a film, ''[[Pale Blue Dot (film)|Pale Blue Dot]]'', based on the events of the case, with [[Natalie Portman]] expected to star as "Lucy Cola", a fictionalized version of Nowak.Kit, Borys; Galuppo, Mia (2018-01-11). Natalie Portman to Star in Astronaut Drama 'Pale Blue Dot'. The Hollywood Reporter, 11 January 2018. Retrieved on 2018-06-04 from https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/natalie-portman-star-astronaut-drama-pale-blue-dot-1073876. ==Personal life== Nowak married Richard T. Nowak, a classmate at both the [[U.S. Naval Academy]] and naval flight school, in 1988.{{Cite news |first=Nell |last=Boyce |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=7226705 |title=Astronaut Faces Attempted-Murder Charges |work=All Things Considered |publisher=NPR |date=February 6, 2007 |accessdate=February 6, 2006}} Richard Nowak was employed by a contractor to NASA at Johnson Space Center while concurrently continuing to fly for the Navy as an officer in the Naval Air Reserve.{{Cite news |last=Schneider |first=Mike |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17031472/ns/technology_and_science-space/ |title=NASA to Review Screening Process |agency=Associated Press |date=February 7, 2007 |accessdate=March 17, 2011}} The Nowaks have three children, a son born in 1992 and twin daughters born in 2001.{{Cite news |last=McLaughlin |first=Moira E. |url=http://www.cathstan.org/news/10-26-06/2.shtml |title=Shuttle astronaut visits Stone Ridge |publisher=The Catholic Standard |date=October 26, 2006 |accessdate=February 6, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070212064422/http://www.cathstan.org/news/10-26-06/2.shtml |archivedate=February 12, 2007}} A statement from the family indicated that the Nowaks separated in January 2007{{Cite web |title=Statement From the Family of Lisa Nowak |author=EarthTimes.org |publisher=EarthTimes.org |date=February 6, 2007 |url=http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/news_press_release,56581.shtml |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120729192405/http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/news_press_release,56581.shtml |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 29, 2012 |accessdate=February 6, 2007}} and subsequently divorced.[http://www.navytimes.com/news/2009/05/gns_nowak_insanity_defense_051509/ Ex-astronaut Nowak dumps insanity defense – Navy News, news from Iraq – Navy Times] Immediately following William Oefelein's divorce, he and Lisa Nowak became involved with each other. Their affair lasted two years, with Oefelein beginning to break it off gradually near the end of 2006. It was during this time that Oefelein started a relationship with Colleen Shipman, who was working as an engineer with the [[45th Space Wing]] at [[Patrick Air Force Base]], Florida.{{Cite news |last=Kluger |first=Jeffrey |url=http://www.time.com/time/health/article/0,8599,1587075,00.html |title=Houston, She's Got Some Problems |publisher=TIME |date=February 8, 2007 |accessdate=February 10, 2007}}{{Cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/TheLaw/story?id=3112215&page=1 |title=Before Alleged Assault, Ex-Astronaut Nowak Was on the Outs at NASA |accessdate=January 21, 2008 |publisher=ABC News |year=2007 |author=Gina Sunseri}}{{Cite news|last=Lundy |first=Sarah |coauthors= |title=Former astronaut Lisa Nowak's attitude cost her mission |work= |pages= |language= |publisher=Orlando Sun-Sentinel |date=May 2, 2007 |url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/local/florida/orl-mnowak0207may02,0,2172150.story?coll=sfla-news-florida |accessdate=May 15, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929105244/http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/local/florida/orl-mnowak0207may02%2C0%2C2172150.story?coll=sfla-news-florida |archivedate=September 29, 2007 |df= }} ==Charges of attempted kidnapping at Orlando Airport== Nowak drove from Houston to Orlando, Florida, on February 4–5, 2007. She packed latex gloves, a black wig, a [[BB gun|BB pistol]] and ammunition, [[pepper spray]], a hooded tan trench coat, a {{convert|2|lb|adj=on}} drilling hammer, black gloves, rubber tubing, plastic garbage bags, approximately {{US$|585|2007}} in cash, her computer, an {{convert|8|in|adj=on}} [[Gerber Legendary Blades|Gerber]] folding knife and several other items before driving the {{convert|900|mi}} to Florida. Early police reports indicated she wore [[Maximum Absorbency Garment]]s during the trip, but she later denied wearing them.{{Cite news|last=Reed |first=Travis |title=Former astronaut wants evidence thrown out |url=http://apnews.myway.com/article/20070919/D8ROJMJ00.html |agency=Associated Press |date=September 19, 2007 |accessdate=September 30, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026011659/http://apnews.myway.com/article/20070919/D8ROJMJ00.html |archivedate=October 26, 2007 }}{{Cite news |last=Schneider |first=Mike |title=Lawyer: Ex-astronaut didn't wear diaper |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/19508417/ |agency=Associated Press |date=June 29, 2007 |accessdate=September 20, 2007}} On February 5, 2007, Nowak went to the [[Orlando International Airport]], waited for about an hour in the baggage claim, and then proceeded to the airport parking lot, where she located and confronted Shipman, who had just arrived from Houston by plane.{{Cite news |last=Ellis |first=Jim |title=Nowak's Car Had Bondage Photos, Pills |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory?id=3027911&CMP=OTC-RSSFeeds0312 |agency=Associated Press |date=April 10, 2007 |accessdate=September 30, 2007}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Shipman said that after arriving, she was aware of someone following her to an airport satellite parking area.{{cite web |url=http://www.thesmokinggun.com/file/astronaut-nabbed-murder-plot?page=1 |title=Astronaut Nabbed in Murder Plot |publisher=The Smoking Gun |date=February 6, 2007 |accessdate=February 24, 2012 |pages=6}} When she got into her car, she heard running footsteps and quickly locked the door. Nowak slapped the window and tried to open the car door, asked for a ride, then started crying. Shipman rolled down the window a couple of inches after which Nowak sprayed the pepper spray into the car. Shipman drove off to the parking lot booth where police were summoned. Several [[Orlando Police Department]] Airport Division officers arrived minutes later, with the first officer observing Nowak throwing a bag into the trash at a parking shuttle bus stop. Nowak was subsequently arrested at Orlando International Airport on charges of attempted kidnapping, battery, attempted vehicle burglary with battery, and [[destruction of evidence]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/space/orl-pdf-nowakaffidavit,0,1599643.acrobat?coll=orl-home-headlines |title=Second charging affidavit, Orlando Police |author=Orlando Police Department |format=PDF |publisher=Orlando Sentinel/Orlando Police |date=February 6, 2007 |accessdate=June 24, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{Cite web |title=Orlando Police Department forensic examination report |author=Orlando Police Department |publisher=Orlando Police/KHOU.com |url=http://www.khou.com/images/0704/nowak1.pdf |format=PDF |date=March 12, 2007}}{{Cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/02/06/national/main2438514.shtml |title=Astronaut Nabbed In Bizarre Kidnap Plot |accessdate=January 21, 2008 |publisher=[[CBS News]] |author=[[CBS]]/[[Associated Press]] |date=February 6, 2007}} In a handwritten request for a [[restraining order]] against Nowak after her arrest, Shipman referred to Nowak as an acquaintance of a boyfriend but did not identify Oefelein, and also claimed Nowak had been stalking her for two months.{{Cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/02/06/astronaut.arrested/index.html |title=Astronaut granted bond on attempted murder charge |accessdate=January 21, 2008 |publisher=CNN |year=2007 |author=CNN}} Nowak told investigators she was involved in a relationship with Oefelein which she described as being "more than a working relationship but less than a romantic relationship". Citing evidence of elaborate planning, disguises and weapons, police recommended she be held without bail.{{Cite news |last=Watson |first=Traci |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2007-02-05-astronaut-arrested_x.htm?POE=NEWISVA |title=Astronaut posts bail after being charged with attempted first-degree murder |publisher=[[USA Today]] |date=February 7, 2007 |accessdate=February 7, 2007}}{{Cite web |title=Orlando Police Department charging affidavit |publisher=Florida Today |author=Orlando Police |date=February 5, 2007 |url=http://www.floridatoday.com/assets/pdf/A96043925.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=February 6, 2007}} ===Arraignment=== Two fellow astronauts traveled to Florida for Nowak's arraignment to assist authorities and NASA personnel as needed:{{Cite news |last=Curtis |first=Henry Pierson |title=Astronaut's victim claims she was stalked |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/orl-mastmain0707feb07,0,4924087.story |publisher=Orlando Sentinel |date=February 7, 2007 |accessdate=February 9, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031030225/http://www.orlandosentinel.com/orl-mastmain0707feb07,0,4924087.story |archivedate=October 31, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} [[Captain (United States O-6)|Captain]] [[Christopher Ferguson]], the senior active duty Naval Officer in the NASA Astronaut Corps at the time, went as Nowak's commanding officer, and retired Air Force Colonel [[Steven Lindsey]], who was the commander of Nowak's shuttle mission, STS-121, went as [[Chief of the Astronaut Office]], the senior astronaut at NASA. On February 6, 2007, both appeared before a judge on her behalf. The state's attorney argued that the facts indicated a well thought out plan to kidnap and perhaps to injure Shipman. While arguing for pre-trial release Nowak's attorney remarked, "One's good works must count for something". Nowak was ordered released on $15,500 bail under the condition she wear a [[GPS]] [[Electronic tagging|tracking device]] and not contact Shipman.{{Cite news |title=NASA Astronaut Lisa Nowak Charged With Attempted Kidnapping, Released on Bail |last=Associated Press |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,250415,00.html |work=FoxNews.com |date=February 6, 2007 |accessdate=February 6, 2007}} Before Nowak could be released, however, Orlando police charged Nowak with attempted first-degree murder and announced she would not be released on bail. Her lawyer alleged that police and prosecutors, unhappy that Nowak had been granted bail, pressed more serious charges solely to keep her confined to jail.{{Cite news |last=Curtis |first=Henry Pierson |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/space/orl-bk-nasaastronaut0507feb05,0,6104316.story?coll=orl-home-headlines |title=Space shuttle astronaut arrested at OIA on attempted kidnapping, battery charges |publisher=Orlando Sentinel |date=February 6, 2007 |accessdate=February 6, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070208053338/http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/space/orl-bk-nasaastronaut0507feb05,0,6104316.story?coll=orl-home-headlines |archivedate=February 8, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} In the second [[arraignment]] Nowak was charged with attempted first-degree murder with a deadly weapon, for which the judge raised bail by $10,000. After posting bail, Nowak was released from jail. Shipman dropped her request for a protection order on February 15.{{Cite news |url=http://www.theledger.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070218/NEWS/702180378/1004 |title=Petition Against Nowak Is Dropped |accessdate=January 21, 2008 |publisher=The Ledger |year=2007 |agency=The Associated Press}} ===Reactions=== There was widespread reaction to Nowak's arrest with concerns expressed about NASA's astronaut selection and screening process and planned 30-month missions to Mars.{{Cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/TECH/space/03/01/griffin.nowak/index.html |title=NASA chief: We didn't recognize Nowak was troubled |author=CNN |publisher=CNN |accessdate=March 6, 2007 |date=March 2, 2007}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/22261045/ |title=Terms of endearment buried in e-mails |accessdate=January 21, 2008 |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |year=2007 |author=MSNBC}} Some indicated that NASA's presentation of astronauts as heroes is part of the problem because of the social pressure.{{Cite news |last=Borenstein |first=Seth |url=http://apnews.myway.com/article/20070209/D8N62FQG0.html |title=Astronaut Culture Stresses Achievement |agency=Associated Press |date=February 9, 2007 |accessdate=February 9, 2007}} Some perceived her treatment in the criminal process as lenient.{{Cite web |url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/static/ceb/2007/09/02/oped/mayette.q..tabada.matamata.html |title=Back to the future |accessdate=January 21, 2008 |publisher=Sun.Star Publishing, Inc. |year=2007 |author=Mayette Q. Tabada }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Others have been shocked that her criminal behavior has been the subject of parody.{{Cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,250415,00.html |title=NASA Astronaut Lisa Nowak Charged With Attempted Murder in Bizarre Love Triangle |accessdate=January 21, 2008 |publisher=Fox News |author=Fox News |date=February 7, 2007}}{{Cite news |last=Rivenburg |first=Roy |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/science/la-spacediaper9feb10,0,2527297.story?coll=la-home-headlines |title=NASA diapers become topic No. 1 |publisher=Los Angeles Times |date=February 9, 2007 |accessdate=November 18, 2007}}{{Cite news |url=http://kennebecjournal.mainetoday.com/view/columns/3618016.html |title=The public stoning of Lisa Nowak |author=Editorial |publisher=Kennebec Journal |date=February 15, 2007 |accessdate=June 24, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070610190305/http://kennebecjournal.mainetoday.com/view/columns/3618016.html |archivedate=June 10, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}; {{Cite news |url=http://www.ifeminists.net/e107_plugins/content/content.php?content.90 |title=No More Jokes About Lisa Nowak, Please |author=David K.M. Klaus |publisher=ifeminists.com |date=February 10, 2007 |accessdate=June 24, 2007 }} [[NASA Administrator]] [[Michael D. Griffin]] commissioned the NASA Astronaut Health Care System Review Committee, an independent panel, to examine how well NASA attended to the mental health of its astronauts. The initial report released by the panel raised questions in regards to possible alcohol use prior to flight.{{Cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/science/space/2007-07-26-astronauts-drinking_n.htm |title=Report uncovers allegations of astronauts drunk on flights |accessdate=August 29, 2007 |publisher=USA Today |author=Traci Watson |date=July 27, 2007}} The report, however, offered no specifics, no facts to substantiate the claims, and stated that no attempt to confirm or investigate the allegations had been performed.{{Cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/TECH/space/08/08/shuttle.commander/index.html |title=Shuttle commander: Alcohol report lacks facts |accessdate=August 29, 2007 |publisher=CNN |author=Miles O'Brien |date=August 8, 2007}}{{Cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/08/29/tech/main3215705.shtml |title=NASA Probe Likely To Clear Drinking Charge |accessdate=August 29, 2007 |publisher=CBS |author=CBS News/Associated Press |date=August 29, 2007}} Shuttle Commander [[Scott Kelly (astronaut)|Scott Kelly]] was vocal in his criticism of the report during interviews prior to STS-118, stating it was beyond his comprehension that astronauts would ever consider what was suggested. Following the release of the independent panel report, NASA ordered an internal review, The Space Flight Safety Review. On August 29, 2007, Chief Safety and Mission Assurance Officer [[Bryan O'Connor]] reported that after the month-long review, NASA found there was no evidence to verify the independent panel's report that astronauts have been allowed to fly drunk.{{Cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/science/space/2007-08-29-nasa-drinking-astronauts_N.htm |title=NASA: No evidence of drunk astronauts |accessdate=August 29, 2007 |publisher=USA Today |year=2007 |author=Traci Watson}}{{Cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/TECH/science/08/28/nasa.astronauts/index.html |title=NASA report: No evidence astronauts flew drunk |accessdate=August 29, 2007 |publisher=CNN |author=Miles O'Brien |date=August 29, 2007}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/audience/formedia/features/astronautreport.html |title=Findings of NASA Safety Review Following Astronaut Health Reviews |accessdate=August 29, 2007 |publisher=NASA |year=2007 |author=NASA}} Additionally, investigation into all incident reports dating from 1984 to 2007, found no incident involving alcohol or drug use.{{Cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/pdf/188111main_Astronaut_Alcohol_Use_Report_final.pdf |title=Space Flight Safety Review (Alcohol Use In The Preflight Period) |accessdate=August 29, 2007 |publisher=NASA Office of Safety and Mission Assurance |year=2007 |author=Bryan O'Conner |format=PDF}} The report's findings specifically stated: {{quote|The culture of professionalism in today's astronaut corps, along with the highly visible, structured and supervised schedule during the last several days prior to launch, provide reasonable controls to avoid flying an alcohol-impaired crewmember. In light of all the other controls in place on launch day, the L-0 flight surgeon check provides a reasonable likelihood of identifying signs of illness or impairment of the level that would threaten flight safety.}} In response to the internal review, policies at NASA would be changed in a variety of ways: flight surgeons would be present during the pre-mission suit-up activities, flight surgeons would receive additional training in psychiatric evaluation, and although there was an unofficial code of conduct in place, an official "Code of Conduct" would be written up for employees. ===Evidence released before trial=== On April 10, 2007, Florida prosecutors released additional material in the case. The previous week, the trial judge had agreed to unseal some of the documents that described items found in Nowak's car after her arrest. Among these items were a handwritten note on {{USS|Nimitz|CVN-68|6}} stationery listing Shipman's flight information and "Flight Controller's Log" paper with a handwritten list of more than 24 items, including sneakers, plastic gloves, contacts, cash, an umbrella, and black sweats. A [[floppy disk]] contained two photographs of Nowak riding in a bicycle race, and 15 images depicting an unidentified woman in different stages of undress. An evidence report dated March 15 indicated that nearly all of the photographs and drawings depicted scenes of bondage.{{Cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,265170,00.html |title=Police Discover Bondage Images in Car of Lovesick NASA Astronaut Lisa Nowak |accessdate=January 21, 2008 |publisher=Fox News |author=Fox News |date=April 10, 2007}} Also found were $585.00 (USD) and £41.00 ([[British pound|GBP]]) in cash and 4 brown paper bags with 69 orange pills that were not publicly identified. Investigators also examined two [[USB flash drive|USB drives]] found in the car. They contained family pictures, digital movies, and NASA-related materials. Investigators concluded that the information on the disk and USB drives did not have any direct relationship to the alleged kidnapping attempt.{{Cite news |last=Ellis |first=Jim |title=Nowak's Car Had Bondage Photos, Pills |work= |pages= |agency=Associated Press |date=April 10, 2007}} Oefelein reportedly provided Nowak with a cell phone to communicate with him. Phone records show that she called him at least 12 times, and sent 7 text messages the day after he returned from his shuttle flight on December 22 that he did not retrieve until December 24 when they had a 7-minute conversation. During December and January, over 100 calls were recorded, although it is unclear who called whom. Under questioning by NASA and military investigators, Oefelein reportedly stated that he had broken off the relationship with Nowak. He did, however, have her to lunch in his apartment at least once in January, they continued to train together for a bicycle race, and they also went to the gym together.{{Cite news |last=Sunseri |first=Gina |title=Ex-astronaut Lisa Nowak's lawyer considers insanity plea |work= |publisher=ABC13.com |date=May 11, 2007 |url=http://abclocal.go.com/ktrk/story?section=local&id=5296676 |accessdate=May 15, 2007}}{{Cite news |last=Schneider |first=Mike |title=New Documents Paint Portrait of Fallen NASA Astronaut |work= |publisher=Space.com |date=May 2, 2007 |url=http://www.space.com/news/ap_070502_nowak_documents.html |accessdate=May 15, 2007}} On May 11, 2007, authorities released a surveillance video from the Orlando International Airport terminal purporting to show Nowak waiting for nearly an hour, standing near the baggage claim, then donning a trench coat and later following Shipman after she retrieved her bags.{{Cite news |last= |first= |coauthors= |title=Ex-astronaut Lisa Nowak's lawyer considers insanity plea |work= |agency=Associated Press |date=May 11, 2007 |url=http://abclocal.go.com/ktrk/story?section=local&id=5297758 |accessdate=May 15, 2007}} ===Developments in case=== On February 13, 2007, Nowak pleaded not guilty to the charges of attempted murder and attempted kidnapping. On March 2, Florida prosecutors filed three formal charges against Nowak: (1) attempted kidnapping with intent to inflict bodily harm or terrorize, (2) burglary of a conveyance with a weapon, and (3) battery.{{Cite web |url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/chronicle/4598826.html |title=Astronaut won't face attempted murder |accessdate=January 21, 2008 |publisher=Houston Chronicle |year=2007 |author=Kim Cobb, Mark Carreau}} The prosecutors declined to file the attempted murder charge that had been recommended by Orlando police. Nowak formally entered a plea of not guilty to the kidnapping charges on March 22 at an arraignment hearing although she was not present in person. Nowak's attorney, who filed the plea with the Orange County court, requested a jury trial. The trial was originally due to commence on July 30, 2007, but was postponed until April 7, 2008, to allow the prosecution time to prepare for an anticipated [[insanity defense]]. On January 16, 2008, a judge postponed the trial, as well as the pre-trial hearing to be held on March 12, 2008, indefinitely, pending the outcome of the state's appeal of an earlier decision to suppress evidence obtained on the day of her arrest.{{Cite news|last=Moore |first=Kimberley C. |url=http://www.floridatoday.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070217/NEWS02/702170336/1007 |title=Judge Sets Nowak's Trial Date |publisher=Central Florida News 13 |date=February 18, 2007 |accessdate=February 18, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070315032420/http://www.floridatoday.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20070217%2FNEWS02%2F702170336%2F1007 |archivedate=March 15, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{Cite news |last=Lundy |first=Sarah |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/volusia/orl-nowak1708jan17,0,7794393.story |title=Appeal freezes trial for ex-astronaut Lisa Nowak |publisher=Orlando Sentinel |date=January 17, 2008 |accessdate=January 20, 2008}} A pre-trial hearing was held on July 17, 2007, and further hearings were to be held on September 19, to argue defense motions to suppress some of the evidence obtained on the day of her arrest.{{Cite news|last=Schweers |first=Jeff |title=Hearing in Lisa Nowak case delayed |work=Florida Today |pages= |publisher=Hearst Corporation |date=March 2, 2007 |url=http://www.floridatoday.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070409/BREAKINGNEWS/70409009/1007 |accessdate=April 12, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930030747/http://www.floridatoday.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20070409%2FBREAKINGNEWS%2F70409009%2F1007 |archivedate=September 30, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{Cite news |last= |first= |coauthors= |title=Ex-astronaut pleads not guilty to kidnap charge |work=CNN |agency=Associated Press |date=March 22, 2007}} On August 12, 2007, Nowak asked to have her GPS ankle bracelet removed,{{Cite web |url=http://www.space.com/news/070824_ap_nowak_courtupdate.html |title=Ex-Astronaut Wants Ankle Bracelet Off |accessdate=January 21, 2008 |publisher=Space.com |year=2007 |author=Travis Reed}} which the judge agreed to on August 30.{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/domesticNews/idUSN3027875220070830 |title=Ex-astronaut Nowak allowed to shed ankle bracelet |accessdate=January 21, 2008 |publisher=Reuters |author=Barbara Liston |date=August 30, 2007}} On August 28, the trial judge unsealed a court document indicating that Nowak intended to pursue an insanity defense. According to documents submitted by her lawyer, Nowak was evaluated by two psychiatrists who diagnosed her with [[obsessive-compulsive personality disorder]], [[Asperger syndrome]], a single episode of [[major depressive disorder]] and a "[[brief psychotic disorder]] with marked stressors" at the time of the incident.{{Cite news |url=http://www.chron.com/news/nation-world/article/Nowak-insanity-defense-raises-issues-for-NASA-1823124.php |title=Nowak insanity defense raises issues for NASA |accessdate=June 24, 2017 |publisher=[[Houston Chronicle]]|date=August 28, 2007}}{{Cite news |url=http://archive.tcpalm.com/news/ex-astronaut-nowak-jettisons-insanity-defense-ep-399131058-347438361.html/ |title=Ex-astronaut Nowak jettisons insanity defense |last=Moore |first=Kimberly C. |accessdate=June 24, 2017 |publisher=TCPalm |date=May 15, 2009}}{{Cite news |url=http://www.newsweek.com/lisa-nowak-what-happened-girl-i-knew-76713 |title=Lisa Nowak: What happened to the girl I knew? |last=Kalb |first=Claudia |accessdate=June 24, 2017 |publisher=[[Newsweek]]|date=November 11, 2009}} On November 2, 2007, the trial judge suppressed Nowak's initial (pre-[[Miranda warning|Miranda]]) statements to police, as well as all evidence found in her vehicle, citing police misconduct in their initial search and questioning.{{Cite web |url=http://www.wesh.com/news/14498841/detail.html |title=Judge: Evidence From Nowak's Car Not Allowed In Court |accessdate=January 21, 2008 |publisher=WESH Channel 2 NBC |year=2007 |author=WESH.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105203944/http://www.wesh.com/news/14498841/detail.html |archivedate=January 5, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} The prosecution appealed that ruling on November 8. A hearing on that appeal occurred on October 21, 2008.{{Cite web |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/orl-lisa-nowak-hearing-090908,0,2006179.story |title=Hearing set for October 21 in Lisa Nowak case |accessdate=September 11, 2008 |publisher=Orlando Sentinel |year=2008 |author=Sarah Lundy }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{Cite web |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/space/orl-lisa-nowak-102108,0,4558714.story |title=Court hears arguments in Lisa Nowak case |accessdate=October 21, 2008 |publisher=Orlando Sentinel |year=2008 |author=Sarah Lundy |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081024094120/http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/space/orl-lisa-nowak-102108,0,4558714.story |archivedate=October 24, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.floridatoday.com/article/20090402/NEWS02/904020331/1006/NEWS01 |title=Nowak to undergo testing |accessdate=2009-04-02 |publisher=Florida Today |author=Kimberly C. Moore }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} On December 5, 2008, the [[Florida Fifth District Court of Appeal]] held that her statements were taken in violation of her ''Miranda'' rights, but that the search of her car was still valid under the inevitable discovery exception to the search warrant requirement because the police would have inevitably found it in the normal course of the investigation despite her illegal statement. The case was sent back for trial. A pre-trial status hearing was scheduled for June 22, 2009. On April 1, 2009, the judge ordered Nowak to undergo two psychiatric evaluations before June 12, 2009.{{Cite web |url=http://www.5dca.org/Opinions/Opin2008/120108/5D07-3833.pdf |format=PDF |title=In the district court of appeal of the state of Florida, fifth district |date=December 5, 2008 |accessdate=June 24, 2009}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.floridatoday.com/article/20090302/BREAKINGNEWS/90302013/1006/NEWS01 |title=Court schedules hearing in Nowak case |accessdate=March 16, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150721111651/http://www.floridatoday.com/article/20090302/BREAKINGNEWS/90302013/1006/NEWS01 |archivedate=July 21, 2015 }} On May 15, 2009, it was reported that Nowak would not claim insanity if her case ever went to trial. Nowak's attorney withdrew a previous motion filed in 2007, which would have left open the opportunity to use an insanity defense in the case. On October 7, 2009, a judge in Orlando ruled in favor of allowing Nowak's attorneys to take a second deposition from Shipman to inquire whether Nowak actually pepper-sprayed Shipman. A medical report by paramedics raised some questions according to Nowak's attorneys as to the factual basis for it. If it was found not to have occurred, Nowak's attorneys wanted the criminal charges related to the assault and battery to be dropped before trial began. The trial was scheduled for December 7, 2009. On November 10, 2009, Nowak entered a guilty plea to lesser charges. She was sentenced to a year's probation and the two days already served in jail, with no additional jail time.{{Cite news |last=Hauser |first=Christine |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/06/us/06cnd-astronaut.html?pagewanted=1&ei=5088&en=e460bff9d1a01979&ex=1328418000&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss |title=Astronaut Charged with Attempted Kidnapping |publisher=New York Times |date=February 6, 2007 |accessdate=February 6, 2007}}[http://www.click2houston.com/news/21570150/detail.html Ex-Astronaut Nowak Pleads Guilty – Houston News Story – KPRC Houston] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091112021659/http://www.click2houston.com/news/21570150/detail.html |date=November 12, 2009 }}{{Cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,573623,00.html?test=latestnews |work=Fox News |title=Ex-Astronaut Lisa Nowak Pleads Guilty to Burglary, Battery but Gets Light Sentence |date=November 11, 2009}}{{cite web|title= Google News |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gWQm10mFUVswAuT1qGmomy6HLkDAD9BSRAUO0 |accessdate=November 10, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2010/02/01/Navy-mulls-punishment-for-ex-astronaut/UPI-76311265039417/ Navy mulls punishment for ex-astronaut – UPI.com] On August 19, 2010, a Naval administrative panel of three admirals voted to recommend Nowak be separated from the U.S. Navy with an "other than honorable" discharge and that her rank be reduced from Captain to Commander. The panel's recommendation would be reviewed by the [[Bureau of Naval Personnel|Naval Personnel Command]] and would ultimately be determined by the [[Secretary of the Navy]].{{Cite news |title=Ex-Astronaut Lisa Nowak May be Dishonorably Discharged from Navy |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-20014259-504083.html |accessdate=August 20, 2010 |work=CBS News |date=August 20, 2010 |first=Caroline |last=Black}} In March 2011, Nowak petitioned the court to seal the record of her criminal proceedings, citing harm to her family and their livelihood.{{Cite news |url=http://www.firstcoastnews.com/rss/article/196697/3/New-Former-Astronaut-Lisa-Nowak-wants-Record-Sealed |title=Former Astronaut Lisa Nowak wants Record Sealed |newspaper=First Coast News |date=March 17, 2011 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |location=[[Orlando, Florida]] |accessdate=May 3, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120904134454/http://www.firstcoastnews.com/rss/article/196697/3/New-Former-Astronaut-Lisa-Nowak-wants-Record-Sealed |archivedate=September 4, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} The motion was granted.{{Cite news | title=Lisa Nowak: Records sealed in NASA astronaut's love-triangle arrest|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2012-01-18/news/os-lisa-nowak-love-triangle-sealed-20120118_1_lisa-nowak-shipman-with-pepper-spray-shipman-and-oefelein|publisher=''[[Orlando Sentinel]]''|date=January 18, 2012}}. Retrieved April 21, 2016 On July 28, 2011, [[Assistant Secretary of the Navy (Manpower and Reserve Affairs)|Assistant Secretary of Navy]] [[Juan M. Garcia III]] said in a statement that Nowak would retire with an "other than honorable" discharge and her pay grade would be reduced one rank.{{Cite news |title=Ex-astronaut Nowak dropped from the Navy |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/07/28/national/main20085167.shtml |accessdate=August 20, 2010 |work=CBS News |date=July 28, 2011}} ==In popular culture== {{refimprove section|date=September 2017}} Nowak's love triangle crimes were the subject of an episode of the US TV news series ''[[20/20 (U.S. TV series)|20/20]]'' entitled "Over the Line".{{cite web|title=20/20 - Over the Line|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/2020-on-id-2012/episode-9-season-2/over-the-line/326793/|website=TVGuide.com|accessdate=3 March 2017|language=en|date=24 April 2014}} The fictional episode "Rocket Man" of the police procedural ''[[Law & Order: Criminal Intent]]'' was also loosely based on Nowak's story. In the ''[[30 Rock]]'' episode "[[The Fighting Irish]]", [[Liz Lemon]] makes a joke about traveling from Houston to Orlando in under 9 hours. In the movie ''[[Rough Night]]'', the male protagonist Peter is recommended by his friends to enact the "Sad Astronaut", clearly referencing Nowak's road journey from Houston to Florida. A specific element of Nowak's journey (wearing of the adult diapers, which Nowak has since denied), is a plot point utilized in the movie, that has been cited as one of the film's most defining moments {{cite web|title=20/20 - Rough Night's Best Gag is the Sad Astronaut|url=https://www.thecut.com/2017/06/rough-nights-best-gag-is-a-tribute-to-the-diaper-astronaut.html}}. The song "Road Trip" by [[Molly Lewis]] is about Nowak's trip to Orlando and is sung from the inferred perspective of Nowak. Spanish punk pop band [[:es:Airbag (banda española)|Airbag]] wrote a song about Nowak's road trip, "Usted morirá en el espacio" ("You will die in space"), included in their fifth studio album ''Alto Disco'' (Wild Punk Records, 2008). Nowak is also referenced in the [[Ben Folds]] song "Cologne" and the [[Common (rapper)|Common]] song "[[Drivin' Me Wild]]" ("drivin' herself crazy / like the astronaut lady"). In 2017, [[Katie Stelmanis]] portrayed Nowak in the music video for the [[Austra]] single "I Love You More Than You Love Yourself". ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * ''Out There: The In-Depth Story of the Astronaut Love Triangle Case that Shocked America'' – [[Diane Fanning]] – St. Martin's Paperbacks – 2007 – {{ISBN|0-312-94930-8}} ==External links== * [http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/gallery/video/shuttle/sts-121/net56/sts-121_fdh08_02_56.asf Lisa Nowak Inflight Video Interview – Spaceflight Experience] NASA (Windows Media Player) * [http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/gallery/video/shuttle/sts-121/net56/sts121_fd10_2_56.asf Lisa Nowak Inflight Video Interview – Eating and Family Contact] NASA (Windows Media Player) * [http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/gallery/audio/shuttle/sts-121/wave/fd04.wav Lisa Nowak Inflight Audio – Wake Up Call on Flight Day 4 with Her Response] NASA (Wav) {{NASA Astronaut Group 16}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nowak, Lisa}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:American astronauts]] [[Category:American people convicted of assault]] [[Category:American people convicted of burglary]] [[Category:American people of Italian descent]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Naval Postgraduate School alumni]] [[Category:People from Rockville, Maryland]] [[Category:People from Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:People with Asperger syndrome]] [[Category:People with mood disorders]] [[Category:People with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder]] [[Category:United States Naval Academy alumni]] [[Category:United States Naval Flight Officers]] [[Category:United States Naval Test Pilot School alumni]] [[Category:United States Navy astronauts]] [[Category:United States Navy officers]] [[Category:Women astronauts]] [[Category:Women in engineering]] [[Category:Women in the United States Navy]]

revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=November 2016}} {{Dynamic list}}
The following is a list of notable living and deceased members of the [[Knights of Columbus]], the world's largest [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]] family, [[Fraternal and service organizations|fraternal]], [[Volunteering|service]] organization.
==Supreme officers== {{:Supreme Knight of the Knights of Columbus}}
==Politics and public service==
===Judicial branch=== *[[Samuel Alito]], Associate Justice of the [[United States Supreme Court|U.S. Supreme Court]] *[[Timothy T. Cronin]], U.S. Attorney for the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin|Eastern District of Wisconsin]] *[[Kevin Patrick Yeary]], judge of the [[Texas Court of Criminal Appeals]], lawyer in [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]]
===Executive branch=== *[[Carl A. Anderson]], former Special Assistant to the President [[Ronald Reagan]] (1983–1987) and [[Supreme Knight of the Knights of Columbus|Supreme Knight]] of the [[Knights of Columbus]] *[[Martin Patrick Durkin]], Former U.S. [[Secretary of Labor]] *[[Raymond Flynn]], former U.S. [[ambassador]] to the [[Holy See]] and former Democratic [[List of Mayors of Boston, Massachusetts|Mayor]] of [[Boston]] *[[John F. Kennedy]], 35th President of the United States *[[Manuel Lujan Jr.]], Former U.S. [[United States Secretary of the Interior|Secretary of the Interior]] *[[Sargent Shriver]], former U.S. [[ambassador]] to France and first director of the [[Peace Corps]] *[[John Volpe]], former U.S. [[Secretary of Transportation]] and former Governor of [[Massachusetts]] (1961–1963 & 1965–1969)
===Legislative branch=== *[[John Boehner]], [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|former Speaker of the House of Representatives]] *[[Hale Boggs]], former [[Party leaders of the United States House of Representatives|U.S. House Majority Leader]] *[[Richard E. Connell]], former U.S. Representative from New York<ref>{{cite book|title=United States Congressional Serial Set|date=1914|publisher=[[U.S. Government Printing Office]]|page=43|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KNaQxh7RG-4C&pg=RA2-PA43&lpg=RA2-PA43&dq=richard+e.+connell+catholic&source=bl&ots=R2u-MWHEB3&sig=aRk5j25kQnylTh8DyXKGw6mHoPs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiUxMvD-8jZAhVRs1kKHaLwAnU4ChDoAQhXMA0#v=onepage&q=richard%20e.%20connell%20catholic&f=false|accessdate=28 February 2018|language=en}}</ref> *[[John Dingell]], United States Democratic Representative from [[Michigan]] *[[Bob Dornan]], pro-life advocate, actor, and former [[California]] Republican congressman *[[Bernard J. Dwyer]], former U.S. Representative from New Jersey *[[Mike Fitzpatrick]] United States Republican congressman from [[Pennsylvania]] *[[Phil Gingrey]], U.S.Republican Congressman from [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] *[[Andrew P. Harris]], U.S. Republican congressman from [[Maryland]]. *[[Joe Heck]], U.S. Republican congressman from [[Nevada]]. *[[Henry Hyde]], U.S. Republican congressman from Illinois<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.kofc.org/en/news/releases/515788.html | publisher = Knights of Columbus | title = "FEW IN PUBLIC LIFE HAVE SERVED AS WELL," SUPREME KNIGHT SAYS. | date = November 29, 2007 | accessdate = January 23, 2017 }}</ref> *[[Jeff Landry]], United States Republican congressman from [[Louisiana]] *[[Joe Manchin]], United States Senator from [[West Virginia]] *[[Alex X. Mooney]], United States representative from West Virginia *[[John William McCormack|John McCormack]], former [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives]] *[[Bruce Poliquin]], United States Republican representative from Maine *[[Edward R. Roybal]], former Democratic member of the U.S. House of Representatives from California *[[Todd Rokita]] Republican congressman from [[Indiana]] *[[Rick Santorum]], former Republican [[United States Senator]] for [[Pennsylvania]] *[[John G. Schmitz]], former member of the U.S. House of Representatives from Orange County, California
===State governments===
====Governor and Lt. Governor==== *[[Terry Branstad]], Republican [[Governor of Iowa]] *[[Jeb Bush]], former Republican Governor of [[Florida]] *[[Felix Perez Camacho]], Governor of [[Guam]] *[[Hugh Carey]], former Democratic [[Governor of New York]] *[[Thomas Donovan (Illinois)|Thomas Donovan]] [[Lieutenant Governor of Illinois]], 1933-1937 *[[John Engler]], former Republican Governor of Michigan *[[T. John Lesinski]], former [[Lieutenant Governor of Michigan]] *[[Mike Rounds]], United States senator and former Republican Governor of [[South Dakota]] *[[Al Smith]], former Democratic governor of [[New York (state)|New York]], Democratic nominee for President in 1928 *[[J. Emile Verret]], [[Lieutenant Governors of Louisiana|Lieutenant Governor of Louisiana]], 1944–1948 *[[Malcolm Wilson (New York)|Malcolm Wilson]], former [[governor of New York]] *[[John Bel Edwards]], Governor of Louisiana
====State legislators==== *[[Dan Huberty]], member of the [[Texas House of Representatives]] from [[Harris County, Texas]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.texastribune.org/directory/dan-huberty/#ui-tabs-1|title=Rep. Dan Huberty (R-Houston)|work=[[The Texas Tribune]]|accessdate=March 25, 2014}}</ref> *[[Joe Ihm]], member of the [[Missouri House of Representatives]] *[[Frank Mazzei]], member of [[Pennsylvania Senate]].<ref name=Kestenbaum/> * [[Pat Boyd]], [[Connecticut House of Representatives|Connecticut State Representative]]<ref>https://www2.cbia.com/ga/CT_Candidate_Pat_Boyd/-N638364</ref> *[[Paul McMurtry]], Representative in the [[Massachusetts General Court]] *[[Robert F. McPartlin]], Democratic member of the [[Illinois House of Representatives]] from 1960 to 1976.<ref>{{cite news|title=Clark Post To McPartlin|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/54960616/?terms=%22Robert%2BF.%2BMcPartlin%22|accessdate=July 1, 2017|work=Suburbanite Economist|date=January 20, 1960|page=12|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|registration=yes}}</ref> *[[Dennis Paul]], member of the Texas House from Harris County<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dennispaul.com/announcement.html|title=Announcement|publisher=dennispaul.com|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> *[[Thomas P. Sinnett]], member of the [[Illinois House of Representatives]] from 1924 to 1938. Party Floor Leader from 1933 to 1934.<ref>{{cite book | title=Illinois Democracy: A History of the Party and Its Representative Members - Past and Present| last = Townsend | first = Walter A. | publisher=Democrat Historical Association, Inc. | issue=v. III | year=1935 | url=https://archive.org/details/illinoisdemocrac03town | accessdate=July 19, 2018 | page=165}}</ref> *[[Louis Tobacco]], [[New York State Assembly]] Member 62nd District *[[Carlos Truan]], member of both houses of the [[Texas Legislature]]<ref name=truan/> *[[Caesar Trunzo]] Former Republican state senator from [[New York (state)|New York]]. *[[Carl M. Vogel]], member of both houses of the [[Missouri State Legislature]] from [[Jefferson City, Missouri|Jefferson City]]
=====Louisiana===== *[[Bo Ackal]], member of the [[Louisiana House of Representatives]] for [[Iberia Parish, Louisiana|Iberia]] and [[St. Martin Parish, Louisiana|St. Martin]] parishes, 1972–1996<ref>{{cite web|url=http://house.legis.state.la.us/pubinfo/Press_Releases/elias_bo_ackal.htm |title=Public Servant Elias "Bo" Ackal Jr., Succumbs to Cancer |publisher=house.legis.state.la.us |accessdate=June 24, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626111901/http://house.legis.state.la.us/pubinfo/Press_Releases/elias_bo_ackal.htm |archivedate=June 26, 2015 |df= }}</ref> *[[Jeff Arnold (politician)|Jeff Arnold]], member of the Louisiana House of Representatives from [[New Orleans]] *[[Armand Brinkhaus]], former member of both houses of the [[Louisiana State Legislature]] from [[St. Landry Parish, Louisiana|St. Landry Parish]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acadianmuseum.com/legends.php?viewID=188|title=Living Legends: Armand Brinkhaus|publisher=acadiamuseum.com|accessdate=May 23, 2014}}</ref> *[[Edward S. Bopp]], member of the Louisiana House from 1977 to 1984<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bopplawfirm.com/team-view/edward-bopp/|title=Edward S. Bopp|publisher=bopplawfirm.com|accessdate=June 28, 2015}}</ref> *[[Dennis Paul Hebert]], member of the Louisiana House of Representatives, 1972–1996<ref>{{cite web|url=http://obits.theadvocate.com/obituaries/theadvocate/obituary.aspx?n=dennis-p-hebert&pid=175822744&fhid=17442|title=Dennis P. Hebert|work=[[The Advocate (Louisiana)|The Baton Rouge Advocate]]|accessdate=September 13, 2015}}</ref> *[[Eddie J. Lambert]], outgoing member of the Louisiana House of Representative; incoming state senator from [[Prairieville, Louisiana|Prairieville]], Louisiana<ref name=stjohn/> *[[Sam A. LeBlanc III]], member of the Louisiana House of Representatives from 1972 to 1980 for Orleans and Jefferson parishes; resident of [[St. Francisville, Louisiana|St. Francisville]] in [[West Feliciana Parish]] *[[Samuel A. LeBlanc I]], member of the Louisiana House of Representatives from 1912 to 1916; state court judge from 1920 to 1954<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nicholls.edu/apps/library/archives_collections/MS00148.pdf|title=Sam A. LeBlanc Papers|publisher=[[Nicholls State University]], [[Thibodaux, Louisiana]]|accessdate=May 31, 2014}}</ref> *[[Gregory A. Miller]], member of the Louisiana House of Representatives<ref name=miller/> *[[Ricky Templet]], former Louisiana state representative<ref name=templet/> *[[Sam H. Theriot]], former Louisiana state representative<ref name=theriot/>
=====Wisconsin===== *[[William P. Atkinson]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[William Banach]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Charles A. Barnard (Wisconsin)|Charles A. Barnard]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Gregor J. Bock]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Everett E. Bolle]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[John P. Dobyns]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[John L. McEwen]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Gary R. Goyke]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Senate]] *[[Raymond F. Heinzen]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Senate]] *[[Robert T. Huber]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[David E. Hutchison]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Henry J. Janssen]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Eugene S. Kaufman]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Stanley J. Lato]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[James Lynn (Wisconsin)|James Lynn]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Thomas A. Manning]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Dale McKenna]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Senate]] *[[David Mogilka]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Richard C. Nowakowski]], former member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[David D. O'Malley]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Thomas D. Ourada]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Bruce Peloquin]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Senate]] *[[Randall J. Radtke]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Valentine P. Rath]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[James A. Rutkowski]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Mark Ryan (Wisconsin)|Mark Ryan]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Thomas M. Schaus]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Charles J. Schmidt]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] and the [[Wisconsin State Senate]] *[[William A. Schmidt]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Senate]] *[[Edward Stack (Wisconsin)|Edward Stack]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[William T. Sullivan]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Lary J. Swoboda]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Raymond J. Tobiasz]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[William W. Ward]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]] *[[Arthur L. Zimny]], member of the [[Wisconsin State Senate]]
====State judiciary==== *[[W. Patrick Donlin]], Judge of the [[Wisconsin Court of Appeals]]
====Other==== *[[Donald G. Bollinger]], American shipbuilder and state chairman of the [[Louisiana Republican Party]] from 1986 to 1988 *[[Etienne J. Caire]], Louisiana businessman, banker, [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] candidate for [[governor of Louisiana|governor]] in 1928 against [[Huey Long]] *[[Ken Cuccinelli]], Former [[Attorney General of Virginia|Attorney General]] of [[Virginia]], [[Republicanism|Republican]] candidate for [[Governor of Virginia|Governor]] in [[Virginia gubernatorial election, 2013|2013]] *[[James E. Finnegan]], former Attorney General of [[Wisconsin]] *[[John W. Griffin (politician)|John W. Griffin]], politician from [[Ohio]] *[[Vincent B. Murphy]], former New York State Comptroller
===Local government=== *[[Richard J. Daley]], second longest-serving mayor of [[Chicago]] *[[Roman Denissen]], former mayor of [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] *[[Tom Galligan (mayor)|Tom Galligan]], former mayor of [[Jeffersonville, Indiana]] *[[Howard B. Gist Jr.]], former city attorney of [[Alexandria, Louisiana]] *[[Alvan Lafargue]], mayor of [[Sulphur, Louisiana|Sulphut]], Louisiana *[[George B. Mowad]], former mayor of [[Oakdale, Louisiana|Oakdale]], Louisiana *[[Dominic Olejniczak]], former mayor of [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] *[[John F. Shelley]], mayor of San Francisco, [[California]] (1964–1968)
===Other politics and public service=== *[[John Moran Bailey]], chairman of the Democratic National Committee from 1961 to 1968 *[[Alan Keyes]], political activist, author and former diplomat *[[Alvan Lafargue]], physician and mayor of [[Sulphur, Louisiana]], from 1926 to 1938 *[[Tom Pendergast]], Kansas City political boss
===Non-United States===
====Canada==== *[[Leo Bernier]], former [[cabinet minister]] in the [[Ontario]] provincial government *[[François-Philippe Brais]], Canadian lawyer and politician *[[Denis Coderre]], Canadian [[Member of Parliament (Canada)]] *[[Michael Copps Costello]], former mayor of [[Calgary, Alberta]] *[[Chris d'Entremont]], Canadian [[Member of the Legislative Assembly]] in the [[Nova Scotia]] provincial government, former Minister of Health and Acadian Affairs *[[Laurent Desjardins]], former [[cabinet minister]] in the [[Manitoba]] provincial government *[[Bernard Grandmaître]], former [[cabinet minister]] in the [[Ontario]] provincial government *[[James John Edmund Guerin]], Canadian [[House of Commons of Canada|Member of Parliament]], Mayor of Montreal *[[Rob Nicholson]], Canadian [[House of Commons of Canada|Member of Parliament]], [[Minister of Justice]] and [[Attorney General]] *[[Steven Point]], Canadian [[Lieutenant Governor of British Columbia]] *[[Pablo Rodríguez (Canadian politician)|Pablo Rodríguez]], Canadian [[Member of Parliament (Canada)]] *[[Alfred-Valère Roy]], Canadian politician *[[Gerry St. Germain]], Canadian [[Senate of Canada|Senator]] *[[Roger Teillet]], former Canadian [[Minister of Veterans Affairs (Canada)|Minister of Veterans Affairs]] *[[Stephen Woodworth (politician)|Stephen Woodworth]], Canadian [[House of Commons of Canada|Member of Parliament]]
====Philippines==== *[[Hilario Davide Jr.]], 20th Chief Justice of the [[Supreme Court of the Philippines]]
==The Church==
===Saints=== *One bishop of Mexico and canonized in 2006. **[[Saint]] [[Rafael Guizar Valencia]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Jalapa|Archbishop of Jalapa]] (bishop) *Six priests, Mexican Martyrs, canonized in 2000<ref name="history"/> **[[Saint]] [[Miguel de la Mora de la Mora]] (priest) **[[Saint]] [[Cathedral Parish of Saint Patrick in El Paso|Pedro de Jesus Maldonado Lucero]] (priest) **[[Saint]] [[Jose Maria Robles Hurtado]] (priest) **[[Saint]] [[Saints of the Cristero War#Rodrigo Aguilar Alem.C3.A1n|Rodrigo Aguilar Alemán]] (priest) **[[Saint]] [[Saints of the Cristero War#Luis B.C3.A1tiz Sainz|Luis Batiz Sainz]] (priest) **[[Saint]] [[Mateo Correa Magallanes]] (priest) *Two priests and a layman, also Mexican Martyrs, beatified in 2005<ref name="history"/> **[[Beatification|Blessed]] [[Jose Trinidad Rangel Montaño]] (priest) **[[Beatification|Blessed]] [[Andres Sola Molist]] (priest) **[[Beatification|Blessed]] Leonardo Pérez (layman) *Puerto Rican layman beatified in 2001. **[[Beatification|Blessed]] [[Carlos Manuel Rodriguez|Carlos Manuel Cecilio Rodríguez Santiago]] (layman)
===Cardinals=== *Cardinal [[Daniel DiNardo]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Galveston-Houston|Archbishop of Galveston-Houston]] *Cardinal [[John Patrick Foley]], [[Grand Master (order)|former Grand Master]] of the [[Order of the Holy Sepulchre|Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem]], and former President of the [[Pontifical Council for Social Communications]] *Cardinal [[Francis George]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago|former Archbishop of Chicago]] *Cardinal [[William Joseph Levada]], [[Prefect|former Prefect]] of the [[Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith]] and [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of San Francisco|Archbishop Emeritus of San Francisco]] *Cardinal [[Theodore McCarrick]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington|Archbishop Emeritus of Washington, D.C.]] *Cardinal [[Seán Patrick O'Malley]], [[Archbishop of Boston]] *Cardinal [[Justin Rigali]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Philadelphia|Archbishop Emeritus of Philadelphia]] *Cardinal [[Gaudencio Rosales]], [[Roman Catholic Archbishop of Manila|Archbishop Emeritus of Manila]] *Cardinal [[Jaime Sin]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Manila|former Archbishop of Manila]] *Cardinal [[Donald Wuerl]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington|Archbishop of Washington]] *Cardinal [[Luis Antonio Tagle]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Manila|Archbishop of Manila]] *Cardinal [[Timothy Dolan]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York|Archbishop of New York City]]
===Bishops=== *Most Rev. [[Dennis Joseph Sullivan|Dennis J. Sullivan]], [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Camden|Bishop of Camden, New Jersey]] *Most Rev. [[Martin John Amos]], [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Davenport|Bishop of Davenport, Iowa]] *Most Rev. [[Robert Joseph Baker]], [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Birmingham in Alabama|Bishop of Birmingham in Alabama]] *Most Rev. [[Charles J. Chaput]], [[Order of Friars Minor Capuchin|O.F.M. Cap.]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Philadelphia|Archbishop of Philadelphia]] *Most Rev. [[Robert Joseph Cunningham]], [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Syracuse|Bishop of Syracuse, New York]] *Most Rev. [[John Francis Donoghue]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Atlanta|former Archbishop of Atlanta]] *Most Rev. [[Robert Finn (bishop)|Robert William Finn]], [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph|Bishop emeritus of Kansas City-St. Joseph]] *Most Rev. [[Joseph Fiorenza]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Galveston-Houston|Archbishop Emeritus of Galveston-Houston]] *[[Venerable]] Archbishop [[Fulton J. Sheen]], [[Newport, Wales|Titular Archbishop of Newport, Wales]], TV personality *Most Rev. [[Gustavo Garcia-Siller]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of San Antonio|Archbishop of San Antonio]] *Most Rev. [[Emilius Goulet]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Saint Boniface|former Archbishop of St. Boniface]] *Most Rev. [[Charles Pasquale Greco]], [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Alexandria in Louisiana|former Bishop of Alexandria, Louisiana]], and first Supreme Chaplain of the Knights *Most Rev. [[Wilton Daniel Gregory]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Atlanta|Archbishop of Atlanta]] *Most Rev. [[Michael Owen Jackels]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Dubuque|Archbishop of Dubuque, Iowa]] *Most Rev. [[Joseph Edward Kurtz]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Louisville|Archbishop of Louisville]] and President of the [[United States Conference of Catholic Bishops]] *Most Rev. [[Albert LeGatt]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Saint Boniface|Archdiocese of St. Boniface]] *Most Rev. [[William E. Lori]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Baltimore|Archbishop of Baltimore]] and [[Knights of Columbus|Supreme Chaplain]] of the [[Knights of Columbus]] *Most Rev. [[Patrick Joseph McGrath]], [[Roman Catholic Diocese of San Jose in California|Bishop of San Jose, California]] *Most Rev. [[R. Walker Nickless]], [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Sioux City|Bishop of Sioux City, Iowa]] *Most Rev. [[Richard Pates]], [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Des Moines|Bishop of Des Moines, Iowa]]
===Priests=== *Rev. [[James Coyle]], Alabama priest who was murdered on August 11, 1921. Member of Mobile Council 666.<ref name=coyle/> *Rev. [[John B. DeValles]], U.S. Army chaplain *Rev. [[John Anthony Kaiser]], MHM, a missionary priest martyred while serving in Kenya. *[[Venerable]] [[Servant of God]] Rev. [[Michael Joseph McGivney]], founder of the Knights of Columbus *Rev. [[George J. Willmann]]
==Sports and athletics== * [[Lou Albano]], Professional wrestler and actor * [[James J. Braddock]], "The Cinderella Man", former heavyweight boxing champion * [[James Connolly (athlete born 1868)|James Connolly]], first [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] Gold Medal champion in modern times * [[Mike Ditka]], former [[Chicago Bears]] coach * [[Chris Godfrey]], former right guard for the [[New York Giants]] and founder of [http://www.lifeathletes.org/ Life Athletes] * [[Ron Guidry]], pitcher who helped lead the [[New York Yankees]] to a [[World Series]] championship * [[Gil Hodges]], Major League baseball player and former manager who led the 1969 [[New York Mets]] to an improbable [[World Series]] win * [[Tom Kelly (baseball)|Tom Kelly]], first baseman and former manager of the [[Minnesota Twins]] * [[Vince Lombardi#Honors|Vince Lombardi]], former coach of the [[Green Bay Packers]] (The Vincent T. Lombardi Council, No. 6552, Knights of Columbus, in Middletown, New Jersey, is named for him.) * [[Connie Mack]], baseball player, manager, and team owner * [[Bob O'Neil]], former NFL [[Pittsburgh Steelers]], [[New York Titans (football)|New York Titans]], CFL [[Calgary Stampeders]], and [[Montreal Alouettes]] professional football player * [[Floyd Patterson]], former heavyweight boxing champion * [[Babe Ruth]], baseball player for the [[Boston Red Sox]], [[New York Yankees]], and [[Boston Braves (baseball)|Boston Braves]] * [[Jim Sorgi]], former Indianapolis Colts quarterback.<ref name=Annual2013/> * [[Shane Victorino]], [[Boston Red Sox]] baseball player<ref name=Victorino/> * [[Lenny Wilkens]], [[National Basketball Association]]'s second winningest coach
==Military== *[[Frank Castellano]], Commander, US Navy, commanding officer of the {{USS|Bainbridge|DDG-96}} during the [[Maersk Alabama hijacking]]. *[[Daniel Daly]], Gunnery Sergeant, [[United States Marine Corps]], two-time Medal of Honor recipient once described by the commandant of the Marine Corps as "the most outstanding Marine of all time."
==Media== *[[Steve Doocy]], Journalist and anchor for [[Fox and Friends]] *[[Paul A. Fisher]], American author, journalist and U.S. Army veteran *[[Joyce Kilmer]], famous journalist and poet *[[Eduardo Verástegui]], prominent Mexican actor
==Others== *[[Nick Bruno]], president of [[University of Louisiana at Monroe]] *[[Jason O'Toole (musician)|Jason O'Toole]], vocalist, [[Life's Blood]] *[[Jerry Orbach]], American actor *[[Jack Reagan|John Edward "Jack" Reagan]], father of President [[Ronald Reagan]] *[[Paul D. Scully-Power]], [[NASA]] [[astronaut]]
==Fictional== *[[Frank Costanza]] – [[George Costanza]]'s father on ''[[Seinfeld]]'' *[[Silvio Dante]]'s father – ''[[The Sopranos]]'' *[[Doyle Lonnegan]] – ''[[The Sting]]'' *[[John Kelly (NYPD Blue)|John Kelly]] – ''[[NYPD Blue]]''

<ref name=miller>{{cite web|url=http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2011/09/st_charles_parish-based_56th_l.html|title=Mary Sparacello, St. Charles Parish-based 56th Louisiana House district draws trio of hopefuls, September 28, 2011|work=[[New Orleans Times-Picayune]]|accessdate=August 26, 2013}}</ref>
<ref name=stjohn>{{cite web|url=http://www.stjohnchurch.org/main/index.php?page=home|title=St. John the Evangelist Catholic Church|publisher=stjohnchurch.org|accessdate=July 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905085546/http://stjohnchurch.org/main/index.php?page=home|archivedate=September 5, 2011|df=}}</ref>
<ref name=templet>{{cite web|url=http://votesmart.org/bio.php?can_id=93761|title=Rep. Ricky James Templet|publisher=votesmart.org|accessdate=July 9, 2011}}</ref>

Commentary for "[[Lisa's Substitute]]", in ''The Simpsons: The Complete Second Season'' [DVD]. 20th Century Fox. * {{note|4}}D.
