{{Orphan|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Mohammad Naciri | image = Mohammed Naciri 2018.jpg | alt = | caption = Naciri at [[Wilton Park]], November, 2018. | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|07|31}} | birth_place = [[Rabat]], [[Morocco]] | death_place = | nationality = Morocccan | other_names = | occupation = Regional director for the two regional: [[Arab states]] and [[Asia Pacific]] for the [[United Nations]] Entity for [[Gender Equality]] and the Empowerment of Women ([[UN Women]]) | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Mohammad Naciri''' ({{lang-ar|محمد الناصري, born 31 July 1973|Mḥmd ālnāṣry}}) is the regional director for the two regional: [[Arab States]] and Asia Pacific for the [[United Nations]] Entity for [[Gender Equality]] and the Empowerment of Women ([[UN Women]]).<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/mohammed-naciri/women-peace-arab-region_b_10375082.html "We Must Involve Women in Bringing Peace to the Arab Region."] HuffingtonPost.co.uk, 09/06/2016 (Updated 09 June 2016)</ref> He is the first man to hold the post of regional director within UN Women and the only one thus far. A senior United Nations official, Naciri has served with the UN for more than two decades. Prior to his current appointment, he served as deputy regional director, Arab States, UN Women. He belongs to the Naciri family, a long-standing family in [[Morocco]]. Naciri has been engaged in addressing cultural and religious norms from a gendered perspective, creating space for partnerships with religious institutions such as [[:fr:Rabita mohammadia des oulémas|Rabita Mohammedia des Oulémas]] He has spearheaded work on engaging men and boys as agents of change in the region, including through issuing a report on masculinities – the first of its kind in the Arab World.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Naciri is a supporter of the arts. He has been supporting young and up and coming artists from the Arab world.
== Early life == === Family === Naciri was born in [[Rabat]] to a Moroccan father and an Egyptian mother. The [https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naciri Naciri] family is a long-standing family in [[Morocco]], whose members have held various positions in government, academia and the judiciary. The Naciri family is notably a large and ancient family of [[Sahrawi people|Saharan]] origin, present everywhere in [[Morocco]]. They are affiliated with their ancestor Mohamed Ben Nacer (hence their name) founder of the seventeenth century Sufi following bearing their name to [[Tamegroute]] and disciple of Abu Hafs Omar Bin Ahmed Al Ansari who instructed him to inculcate the principles of [[Shadhili|Tariqa Chadhiliyya]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1163/_afco_asc_1532|title=Bibliothèque nationale du Royaume du Maroc (BNRM)|website=African Studies Companion Online}}</ref><ref>SPAULDING, J. (2005). HISTORICAL EXPLORATION OF ISLAMIC SCHOLARSHIP AND EDUCATION The Transmission of Learning in Islamic Africa. Edited by SCOTT S. REESE. Leiden: Brill, 2004. Pp. xiv 307. €95/$136 ({{ISBN|90-04-13779-3}}). ''The Journal of African History,'' ''46''(3), 510-511. doi:10.1017/S002185370523133X</ref>
Notably, Naciri is the grand-nephew of Mohamed El Mekki Naciri, the former Moroccan ambassador to Libya, minister for religious endowments and the owner and chief editor of Al Alam newspaper, former head of Arrabita Al Mohammadia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ghannamonde.populus.org/rub/14|title=MAROC CELEBRITES|website=ghannamonde.populus.org|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://lepsusuber.com/article/mohamed-el-mekki-naciri|title=Mohamed El-Mekki Naciri; Biographie; Veröffentlichungen; Trials; Veröffentlicht Forschungs; Werke ins Arabische übersetzt|website=lepsusuber.com|language=de|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://lematin.ma/journal/2004/Les-qualites-intellectuelles-de-feu-Mekki-Naciri-mises-en-relief/41384.html|title=Le Matin - Les qualités intellectuelles de feu Mekki Naciri, mises en relief|last=MATIN|first=, LE|website=Le Matin|language=fr-FR|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cndh.org.ma/an/national-partners/rabita-mohammedia-des-oulemas-mohammadia-league-scholars|title=Rabita Mohammedia des Oulémas (Mohammadia League of Scholars) {{!}} Conseil National des Droits de l'Homme|website=www.cndh.org.ma|language=an|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.habous.gov.ma/fr/arrabita-al-mohammadia.html|title=Rabita Mohamadia des Oulémas|last=Hamouda|access-date=2018-06-09|language=fr-fr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.arrabita.ma/default.aspx|title=الرابطة المحمدية للعلماء|last=Soft|first=Visual|website=www.arrabita.ma|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://telquel.ma/2017/01/10/rabita-mohammedia-oulemas-lance-site-lutter-contre-discours-extremiste_1530585|title=La Rabita Mohammedia des oulémas lance un site pour lutter contre l'extrémisme|work=Telquel.ma|access-date=2018-06-09|language=fr-FR}}</ref> He is the nephew of [[Khalid Naciri]], the former minister of communication and the spokesperson of the Moroccan government.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-morocco-protest/morocco-government-plays-down-call-for-protests-idUSTRE7128FN20110203|title=Morocco government plays down call for protests|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.eg/books?id=ncqqQra-2ToC&pg=PA214&lpg=PA214&dq=khalid+naciri+morocco&source=bl&ots=1t4RssUB9M&sig=6XJ28oAFOv8AShxHrneCcmIk6kI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjMvo66yMXbAhUPKlAKHYYQArEQ6AEIXzAN#v=onepage&q=khalid%20naciri%20morocco&f=false|title=The Report: Morocco 2011|date=2010|publisher=Oxford Business Group|isbn=9781907065309|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.maghress.com/fr/albayane/11357|title=Nous ne sommes pas à la veille d'une impasse constitutionnelle|work=Maghress|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref> Naciri is also the first cousin of [[Salaheddine Mezouar]], the former foreign minister of Morocco.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.crd.co.ma/s_e_mezouar.asp|title=Membres du CRD / Salah Eddine MEZOUAR|last=crd@crd.co.ma|first=CRD -|website=www.crd.co.ma|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref>
His maternal grandfather is Mohamed Ayoub, a senior member of the Egyptian government, a governor of the Eastern governorate from 1970 to 1975, and a founding member of the [[New Wafd Party|new delegation party]] in 1978.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.egypttoday.com/Article/1/46592/Wafd-Party-members-choose-their-new-leader-on-Friday|title=Wafd Party members choose their new leader on Friday - Egypt Today|website=www.egypttoday.com|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref>
Naciri´s parents were travelling when growing up, he received his primary education in different countries, graduating from High School in the [[United Arab Emirates]].
==Education== Naciri has a master's degree in [[public policy]] and [[international development]] from the [[Kennedy School of Government]], [[Harvard University]] (United States) in 1997-1999. He has a second master's degree in [[social anthropology]] from the Institute of Social and Cultural Anthropology, [[University of Oxford]] (United Kingdom) in 1999-2000 where he was a [[Chevening Scholarship|Chevening]] scholar, and a third [[masters degree]] in [[business administration]] from [[Arab Academy for Science, Technology & Maritime Transport|the Arab Academy for Science, Technology & Maritime Transport]] in [[Alexandria]] ([[Egypt]]) from 1995-1997.
==Career== Naciri began his career as an intern with [[UNICEF]], and has since then stayed in the world of development and human rights.
=== UN Women=== Naciri is an outspoken supporter of women's rights in the region, and the engagement of women in peace processes in particular.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-economy-women/violence-against-women-hurts-arab-economies-u-n-says-idUSKBN1C92M7|title=Violence against women hurts Arab economies, U.N. says|last=Kanso|first=Heba|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en-US}}</ref> Under his leadership, the regional office supported the convening of 45 Yemeni women from different factions to call for an engendered peace process, in his remarks to the meeting, Naciri said, "Yemeni women have an opportunity to contribute in building peace, revitalizing dialogue, and helping Yemen get out from this dark tunnel. We are counting on Yemeni women’s wisdom to create a model that people will follow."<ref>[http://www.unwomen.org/en/news/stories/2015/10/yemeni-women-call-for-their-inclusion-in-peace-efforts "Yemeni women call for their inclusion in peace efforts."] UNWomen.org - 27 October 2015</ref>
Having been appointed immediately after the [[Arab Spring|Arab spring]], much of Naciri's work on [[gender equality]] in the region focused on participation and leadership.<ref>[http://www.deseretnews.com/article/765579888/Writing-history-Muslim-women-reshape-their-destiny-with-newfound-freedom.html?pg=all "Muslim women reshape their destiny with newfound freedom."] - Deseret News - Published: Thursday, May 31, 2012</ref> "We need to look on how can we sustain this participation," Naciri said. "With women, with men, with the country at large, and the government, how can we prove that women's participation is of interest and benefit to the whole society."<ref>[http://arabic.cnn.com/middleeast/2016/06/11/women-iraq-syria-conflict-opinion "Womenin Iraq Syria Conflict."] CNN.</ref>
Under his leadership, UN Women and [[United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia]] (ESCWA) launched regional research on the costing of violence.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://reliefweb.int/report/world/un-women-and-escwa-launch-project-estimate-cost-violence-against-women-arab-region|title=UN Women and ESCWA launch project to estimate the cost of violence against women in the Arab Region|work=ReliefWeb|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en}}</ref> He has spearheaded work on engaging men and boys as agents of change in the region, including through issuing a report on masculinities – the first of its kind in the Arab World.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://imagesmena.org/en/|title=Men and Gender Equality in the Middle East and North Africa|website=Understanding Masculinities|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2017/05/09/middleeast/gender-equality-study-mena/index.html|title=Do Arab men support gender equality?|last=CNN|first=Bianca Britton,|work=CNN|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref>
Naciri has worked on expanding both the scope and partnerships of the regional office. A new concept note for a partnership initiative between [[Union for the Mediterranean]] (UfM), [[UN Women|U.N. Women]] and the [[OECD|Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] on Women and ICTs is already under discussion and, according to Naciri, new expertise in this area will definitely be in demand in the future.<ref>[https://www.devex.com/news/full-speed-ahead-5-ways-to-optimize-women-s-economic-potential-86361 "Full speed ahead: 5 ways to optimize women’s economic potential."] www.Devex.com -19 June 2015</ref>
Naciri has successfully established several partnerships with bilateral development partners, including the EU MADAD trust fund for [[Syria]] response,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://arabstates.unwomen.org/en/news/stories/2017/12/european-union|title=European Union - UN Women partnership bolsters efforts in response to Syrian crisis|work=UN Women {{!}} Arab States/North Africa|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en}}</ref> [[Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency]] (SIDA),<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://arabstates.unwomen.org/en/what-we-do/ending-violence-against-women/men-and-women-for-gender-equality|title=Men and Women for Gender Equality|work=UN Women {{!}} Arab States/North Africa|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en}}</ref> [[Finland]], [[Japan]] and the government of [[Norway]] to mention a few.
Naciri has been engaged in addressing cultural and religious norms from a gendered perspective, creating space for partnerships with religious institutions such as [[:fr:Rabita mohammadia des oulémas|Rabita Mohammedia des Oulémas]]. [[UN Women]] under his leadership successfully advocated for the abolishment of laws that gave clemency to rapists if they married their victims in [[Lebanon]], [[Jordan]], [[Morocco]] and [[Tunisia]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.unwomen.org/en/news/stories/2017/8/news-lebanon-parliament-repeals-rape-law|title=Historic day for women in Lebanon as Parliament repeals rape law|work=UN Women|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/historic-day-for-women-in-lebanon-as-parliament-repeals_us_59a7342de4b096fd8876c04c|title=Historic Day For Women In Lebanon As Parliament Repeals Rape Law|last=Women|first=U. N.|date=2017-08-30|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-40947448|title=Lebanon abolishes rape marriage loophole|date=2017-08-16|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en-GB}}</ref>
====Dubai Lynx 2015==== In 2015 UN Women partnered with [[Dubai]] [[Lynx]], the largest regional advertising festival to highlight violence against women, and encouraged young creatives to come up with a video brief on the issue.<ref>[http://www.unwomen.org/en/news/stories/2015/3/the-7-day-brief-competition-rallies-creatives-in-mena-in-support-of-un-women "The ‘7-Day Brief’ Competition rallies creatives in MENA in support of UN Women."] - UNWomen - 11 March 2015</ref><ref>[http://www.themarketingsite.com/news/39259/dubai-lynx-and-youtube-team-with-un-women-for-day-brief-competition "Dubai Lynx and YouTube Team with UN Women for 7-Day Brief Competition."] - TheMarketingSite.com - 14 Jan 2015</ref><ref>[http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/saudi-duo-addresses-domestic-violence-7-day-brief-un-women/1338227# "Saudi duo addresses domestic violence in 7-Day Brief for UN Women."] Campaignlive.co.uk - March 18, 2015</ref> The regional office shed light on gender taboos through a mother's day campaign which went viral both in the region and beyond. The campaign, highlighting the shame associated with saying one's mother's name, resulted in thousands posting on social media in honor of their mothers.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TEaiZjsopjQ "Dubai Lynx 7 Day Brief 2015: UN Women"] [[YouTube]] -Jan 20, 2015</ref>
===UNDP Yemen=== From 2009 to 2012, Naciri was the deputy country director of the [[United Nations Development Programme]] in [[Yemen]].<ref>[http://reliefweb.int/report/yemen/undp-administrator-signed-two-important-projects-reaffirming-undps-support-yemens "UNDP Administrator signed two important projects reaffirming UNDP's support to the Yemen's development."] - reliefweb.int -Published on 23 Jan 2011</ref> During this time he managed a comprehensive development portfolio including good governance, poverty alleviation and environmental sustainability in line with UNDP strategic priorities and the Yemen development framework.
=== UNDP Kuwait === He was the acting [[UNDP]] [[Kuwait]] resident representative in 2008-2009, working on, among other things, women's empowerment and witnessing the election of female parliamentarians<ref>[http://www.arabstates.undp.org/content/rbas/en/home/presscenter/pressreleases/2009/05/31/-press-releases-news-speeches-for-the-record-media-contacts-general-inquiries-events-elected-women-sworn-in-for-first-time-in-kuwaiti-parliamentary-history.html "Elected women sworn in for first time in Kuwaiti parliamentary history."] -ArabStates.UNDP.org -May 31, 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.kuna.net.kw/ArticlePrintPage.aspx?id=2002154&language=en "Kuwait Women MP's, Moment of Great Promise UNDP"] -Kuna.net.kw -31st of May, 2009</ref> for the first time in the country´s history.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/presscenter/pressreleases/2009/05/31/four-elected-women-sworn-in-for-first-time-in-kuwaiti-parliamentary-history.html|title=Elected women sworn in for first time in Kuwaiti parliamentary history|website=UNDP|language=en|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref> He worked on the transparency index, and updating the fiscal policy of the [[Central Bank of Kuwait]]. He further worked with [[Kuwait]] on the aftermath of the environmental damages caused by the [[Iraq War|Iraq war]] through the burning of oil fields.
===International Organization for Migration === Naciri first served with the [[International Organization for Migration|International Organization For Migration]] (IOM) as a UN Junior Professional Officer Programme in [[Cambodia]]. Here he lobbied for recognition of the [[human trafficking]] atrocities taking place in the country, including supporting a public hearing in the [[United States Congress|US congress]] in 2003 for the US state department trafficking in persons report.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://foreignaffairs.house.gov/hearing/subcommittee-hearing-the-state-department-2013-trafficking-in-persons-report/|title=Subcommittee Hearing: The State Department 2013 Trafficking in Persons Report - Committee on Foreign Affairs|work=Committee on Foreign Affairs|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en-US}}</ref> Naciri raised 10 million USD for IOMs work on trafficking from the US government as a result of this. Following his time in Cambodia, Naciri was appointed as chief of mission for IOM in [[Kuwait]] and tasked with establishing IOMs mission in country. During this time he worked closely with Kuwaiti authorities to include domestic workers under the labor code. Naciri was also in charge of IOMs [[Geography of Iraq|Southern Iraq]] response from [[Kuwait]]. He was also the deputy director for the out of country voting for [[Iraq]] during the 2005 elections. In 2006, during the [[2006 Lebanon War|Lebanon war]], Naciri was seconded to be the IOM emergency coordinator.
== Personal Endeavors ==
# Naciri is a supporter of the arts. In 2008, he was cited by ''Canvas Magazine'', Volume 4, Issue 3 in May–June 2008 as one of the youngest patrons of Middle Eastern art.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.canvasonline.com/canvas_backissue.php|title=Canvas Magazine|last=http://www.avadhsolutions.com/|first=Avadh IT Solutions|website=www.canvasonline.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jMbZ12Wv3j0|title=Paradoxia' Stories: Mohamed Naciri|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He has been supporting young and up and coming artists from the Arab world. He was also featured in the ''Financial Times'' profile of his personal art collection and how it relates to his women´s rights activism.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/2493ee86-a43b-11e7-9e4f-7f5e6a7c98a2|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref> # In 2001, he was featured with an article in Katya Traboulsi´s book ''"Des Autres/Of Others"'' in which he wrote about the relationship between art and people.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Autres-others-Katya-Traboulsi/dp/2360860178|title=Des Autres, Of others|last=results|first=search|date=2011-09-28|publisher=Tamyras Editions|isbn=9782360860173|language=French}}</ref> # In April 2018, Naciri gave a TED X talk on being a Male, Muslim, Arab Feminist at [[Sciences Po|Sciences PO]] [[Menton]] campus.<ref>{{Citation|last=TEDx Talks|title=I am a man, I am a Muslim and yes, I am a feminist {{!}} Mohammad Naciri {{!}} TEDxSciencesPoCampusMenton|date=2018-05-24|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UrI-pPw_RIc|accessdate=2018-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ted.com/tedx/events/24199|title=TEDxSciencesPoCampusMenton {{!}} TED|website=www.ted.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref> In May 2018, Naciri spoke at [[University of Oxford|Oxford University]] on women´s empowerment in the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] (GCC). # In 2016, Naciri spearheaded the IIFMENA conference, including closing remarks and the launching of the Sharjah declaration.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://iifmena.org/public/content/page/1/32|title=IIFMENA Website|website=iifmena.org|language=ar|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sawirisfoundation.org/work/sfsd-participates-in-investing-in-the-future-conference/|title=Sawiris Foundation for Social Development › SFSD Participates in "Investing in The Future" Conference, Sharjah, UAE|website=Sawiris Foundation for Social Development|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sharjah24.ae/en/sharjah/163468-un-women-adopts-sharjah-declaration-for-the-rights-and-empowerment-of-women-and-girls|title=UN Women Adopts ‘Sharjah Declaration’ for the Rights and Empowerment of Women and Girls|work=Sharja24|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en}}</ref> # In 2017, Naciri and UN Women in partnership with [[Instituto Promundo|Promundo]] launched the first regional research on masculinities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://promundoglobal.org/2017/04/27/unveiling-key-findings-images-mena/|title=Unveiling Key Findings From the International Men and Gender Equality Survey in the Middle East and North Africa – Promundo|date=2017-04-27|work=Promundo|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en-US}}</ref> # In November 2015, Naciri and six other high-profile personalities performed an internationally acclaimed documentary play, ''SEVEN'', for the first time in [[Cairo (Egypt)|Cairo]].<ref>[http://voicesprojects.com/portfolio/seven-on-tour/ "Seven on Tour."] - [http://voicesprojects.com/ VoicesProjects]</ref><ref>[https://www.facebook.com/events/419475021594633/ 19 سبعة فى القاهرة / SEVEN on Tour in Cairo Event's page] - Facebook</ref><ref>[https://seventheplay.com/the-story-of-seven/ "The Story of SEVEN."] - SeventhePlay.com</ref> # Naciri is an international jury member of the Global award of Women´s Empowerment, to be awarded in March 2019.<ref>{{Citation|last=Scw Bahrain|title=تشكيل لجنة تحكيم جائزة الأميرة سبيكة العالمية لتمكين المرأة|date=2018-05-04|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oXRwzHxyruY&feature=share|accessdate=2018-06-09}}</ref> # In June 2018, He was a speaker at POLITICO.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://diievents.dii.eu/women-rule-summit/speaker/mohammad-naciri/|title=Mohammad Naciri - Women Rule Summit|work=Women Rule Summit|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.eu/newsletter/london-playbook/politico-london-playbook-brussels-says-no-italy-burns-markets-wheres-melania/|title=POLITICO London Playbook: Brussels says no — Italy burns markets — Where’s Melania?|date=2018-05-30|work=POLITICO|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en-US}}</ref> #In October 2018, He was on the board of Arab Woman Awards 2018, Kuwait.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.kuwaittimes.net/website/arab-woman-awards-kuwait-2018-nominations-open/|title=Arab Woman Awards Kuwait 2018 nominations open - Kuwait Times|date=2018-08-29|work=Kuwait Times|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.kuwaittimes.net/website/arab-woman-awards-kuwait-2018-winners-announced/|title=Arab Woman Awards Kuwait 2018 winners announced - Kuwait Times|date=2018-10-21|work=Kuwait Times|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.arabianbusiness.com/kuwait/406455-arab-woman-awards-kuwait-2018-winners-announced|title=Arab Woman Awards Kuwait 2018 winners announced|work=ArabianBusiness.com|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://arabstates.unwomen.org/en/news/stories/2018/10/women-research-and-studies-center|title=Women Research and Studies Center|work=UN Women {{!}} Arab States/North Africa|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en}}</ref> #In November 2018, He was the Columbia European Society and GEG Columbia guest lecturer on EU Involvement in Arab Female Empowerment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.evensi.com/mohammad-naciri-involvement-arab-female-empowerment/276558553|title=Mohammad Naciri: EU Involvement in Arab Female Empowerment - 7 November 2018|last=Society|first=Columbia European|website=Evensi|access-date=2018-11-27}}</ref> # Naciri was a member of the Blues rowing team while at Oxford and is a [[Black belt (martial arts)|black belt]] [[Shotokan]] Karate practitioner. He was a member of the [[Rotaract]] from 1992-1999.From 1993-1997 was a member of [[AIESEC]].
== Publications == Naciri has been featured in several publications, notably around women´s rights.
* In May 2018 he was featured in Gulf Affairs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.oxgaps.org/files/interview_-_naciri.pdf|title=Gulf A airs: What is the mission of UN WOMEN Arab States? Does the organization work di- rectly with Gulf countries? If so, in what ways?|last=|first=|date=|website=Gulf Affairs|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * In February 2018, he co-authored an op-ed calling for the importance of an inclusive peace process in [[Yemen]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/5050/mohammad-naciri-hanan-tabbara/reham-al-bader-yemen-women-conflict-assistance|title=Activist Reham Al-Bader’s death in Yemen shows the dangers women face providing lifelines in conflict|date=2018-02-18|website=openDemocracy|language=en|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref> * In 2017, The [[Union for the Mediterranean]] interviewed him.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ufmsecretariat.org/interview/ufm-interviews-mohammad-naciri/|title=UfM interviews Mohammad Naciri - Union for the Mediterranean - UfM|work=Union for the Mediterranean - UfM|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en-US}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{original research|date=March 2009}} {{in-universe|date=March 2009}} }} {{Infobox character | name = Niki Sanders | series = [[Heroes (U.S. TV series)|Heroes]] | image= [[Image:Niki Sanders.jpg|200px]] | caption = [[Ali Larter]] as Niki Sanders | portrayer = [[Ali Larter]] | first = "[[Genesis (Heroes)|Genesis]]" | last = "[[Powerless (Heroes)|Powerless]]" (alive); "[[One of Us, One of Them]]" (corpse) | lbl21 = Ability |data21 = Enhanced Strength{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/report/0,6115,1553770_3_0_,00.html|title=Heroes: On the set of the hit that's saving the TV season|last=Jensen|first=Jeff|date=2006-11-18|publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly|EW.com]]|pages=6|accessdate=2009-07-13}} | lbl22 = Real name |data22 = Nicole Sanders | alias = Jessica
Gina | spouse = [[D. L. Hawkins]] (husband) | children = [[Micah Sanders]] (son) | family = Hal Sanders (adoptive father)
Jessica Sanders (adoptive sister)
[[Tracy Strauss]] (sister)
Barbara Zimmerman (sister) | lbl23 = Status | data23 = (Deceased) }} '''Nicole Sanders''' is a [[fictional character]] portrayed by [[Ali Larter]] in the television series ''[[Heroes (U.S. TV series)|Heroes]]''. Niki is the wife of [[D. L. Hawkins]] ([[Leonard Roberts]]) and mother of [[Micah Sanders]] ([[Noah Gray-Cabey]]). Niki, a sufferer of [[Dissociative Identity Disorder]], displays superhuman strength, being able to literally rip others in half. Initially, she is able to access this power only when her [[alter ego]] "Jessica" is in control. Killed in an explosion to save Monica. [[Tim Kring]], the creator of the show, stated that he originally created Niki with the power to be in two places at once, which stems from her life as a single mother.{{cite web|author=Standler |title=Heroes Execs discuss show’s future, LOST, more |publisher=OgMog |date=2007-02-07 |url=http://www.ogmog.com/2007/02/07/heroes-execs-discuss-shows-future-lost-more/ |accessdate=2007-03-03 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070223233531/http://www.ogmog.com/2007/02/07/heroes-execs-discuss-shows-future-lost-more/ |archivedate=2007-02-23 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Niki was also originally written to be a [[showgirl]]. However, [[Ali Larter]] did not have the proper physique to portray a showgirl, so the character's profession was changed to [[cam whore|internet stripper]].{{cite web|last=Caylo |first=Mel |title=TV Q&A: Heroes-Jeff Loeb |publisher=Wizard Universe |date=2007-01-20 |url=http://www.wizarduniverse.com/television/heroes/003137244.cfm?page=3 |pages=3 |accessdate=2007-01-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927194407/http://www.wizarduniverse.com/television/heroes/003137244.cfm?page=3 |archivedate=September 27, 2007 }} According to writers Joe Pokaski and Aron Coleite, Niki was written out of the series and replaced with [[Tracy Strauss]] so that Larter could play a different role, as they realized that they could not go further with the character. The change also allowed them to tell an origin story, where the character discovers that she has powers.{{cite web |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=18343 |title=Behind the Eclipse: Week 2 |accessdate=2008-11-04 |author=Pokaski, Joe |author2=Coliete, Aron |date=October 6, 2008 |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]]}} ==Background== One of three [[identical twins|identical triplets]] injected with [[Arthur Petrelli]]'s formula as babies, Niki was adopted by a wealthy father named [[List of characters in Heroes#Hal Sanders|Hal Sanders]]. An [[child abuse|abusive]] [[alcoholic]], Hal would often beat Niki and her sister, Jessica, during his drunken rages. Eventually, Hal strangled Jessica to death and abandoned his remaining daughter. As an adult, Niki had no memory of her father's actions and simply believed he ran out on her. At some point in her life, Niki herself became an alcoholic and a problem gambler, but she managed to overcome her problems. On her first anniversary of [[sobriety]], Niki attended an [[Alcoholics Anonymous]] meeting. There, she was reunited with her father, Hal, who wanted to make amends. Niki introduced Hal to her husband, D. L., and her son, Micah. Hal gave the boy a computer, but when he became angry at his grandson for taking the expensive gift apart, Niki demanded that he leave. After her father's departure, Niki went to confront him as Jessica, claiming to remember everything he did to her, including his responsibility in her death (a memory Niki had apparently been suppressing). After assaulting him, she forced the [[check (finance)|check]] Hal gave Niki into his mouth and ordered him never to contact her again.{{cite episode | title = Six Months Ago | episodelink = Six Months Ago | series = Heroes | serieslink = Heroes (U.S. TV series)| credits = | network = NBC | airdate = 2006-11-27}} ==Plot== ===Genesis=== As of October 2006, Niki resides in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] and struggles to raise her ten-year-old son, [[Micah Sanders|Micah]]. She has been working as an [[Cam whore|internet stripper]] to pay the bills. Her husband, [[D. L. Hawkins]], is in [[prison]], accused of stealing two million [[dollar]]s from a sports booker and murdering his own gang. To help pay for Micah's [[tuition]] at a very expensive school that Niki believed would encourage his gifts, Niki borrowed money from [[List of Heroes characters#Daniel Linderman|Mr. Linderman]] ([[Malcolm McDowell]]), a [[gangster|mobster]] who once employed her husband. Not having enough money to continue paying tuition or repay the loan, she withdraws Micah from the school.{{cite episode | title = Genesis | episodelink = Genesis (Heroes) | series = Heroes | serieslink = Heroes (U.S. TV series)| credits = Director: David Sernel, Writer: Tim Kring | network = NBC | airdate = 2006-09-25}} The two go [[on the lam|on the run]], as they attempt to elude thugs and police that Linderman sends after her. During times of stress, Niki begins seeing her reflection in mirrors and other reflective surfaces moving differently from herself, leading her to be concerned about her sanity. After Linderman sends two thugs to her house to collect the money she owed him, an altercation occurs, with Niki apparently blacking out after being hit by one of the thugs. When Niki recovers consciousness some time later, she is shocked to find the two thugs dead and horribly mutilated.{{cite episode | title = Don’t Look Back | episodelink = Don't Look Back (Heroes) | series = Heroes | serieslink = Heroes (U.S. TV series)| credits = Director: Alan Arkush, Writer: Tim Kring | network = NBC | airdate = 2006-10-02}} Niki has other blackout spells over the following days, one time losing four hours, always with no recollection of what has transpired. Niki eventually realizes that she possesses a [[split personality]] named Jessica, the other being far more sinister and amoral than her usual self, and which possesses [[superhuman strength]]. Niki is reunited with her husband D. L. after he escaped from jail in order to clear his name. Later, Jessica reveals that she was the one who stole the money, killed D. L.'s crew, and framed him, planning to use the money to give her son a better life and keep him away from D. L.'s influence. After a short but violent fight, in which D. L. reveals the phasing powers that he had used to escape from jail, Niki is defeated and lies unmoving on the floor while D. L. takes Micah away.{{cite episode | title = Better Halves | episodelink = Better Halves | series = Heroes | serieslink = Heroes (U.S. TV series)| credits = Director: Greg Beeman, Writer: Natalie Chadez | network = NBC | airdate = 2006-10-30}} The next day, Niki recovers from her injuries and confides in her friend Tina about her dreams and her alternate personality. Jessica then resurfaces and tells Tina that Niki will no longer need Tina's help. That night Jessica answers a telephone call from Micah. She persuades Micah, who knows that she is not his mother, to tell her where he and D. L. are staying.{{cite episode | title = Nothing to Hide | episodelink = Nothing to Hide (Heroes) | series = Heroes | serieslink = Heroes (U.S. TV series)| credits = Director: Donna Dietch, Writer: Jesse Alexander | network = NBC | airdate = 2006-11-06}} Soon after that, Jessica purchases a sniper rifle, and goes in search of D. L. and Micah. When she finally finds them, she takes aim at D. L. from a hidden location across the street and attempts to kill him.{{cite episode | title = Homecoming | episodelink = Homecoming (Heroes) | series = Heroes | serieslink = Heroes (U.S. TV series)| credits = Director: Greg Beeman, Writer: Adam Armus & Kay Foster | network = NBC | airdate = 2006-11-20}} Her first shot hits D. L. in the shoulder, but Jessica is unsuccessful at killing him. After a short chase through the woods, during which Niki fights Jessica for dominance, Jessica attempts to kill D. L. again. She inadvertently throws Micah against some rocks when he tries to restrain her. Horrified, Niki regains control. She apologizes to D. L. and Micah and explains to them her problem. Niki reveals that Jessica is stronger than she is, and that as a result, she can't be trusted. Concerned that Jessica will eventually take over and put her family in danger, Niki turns herself in to the police and confesses to murder. Two weeks later, Niki is in prison, awaiting trial. She is returned to her cell after being in [[solitary confinement]]. The prison staff is very cautious, as Jessica has emerged previously and injured one of the guards during an attempted escape. During a meeting with the [[public defender]] assigned to her case, Niki is informed that the prosecution seeks the [[death penalty]]. Her lawyer asks Niki about the two million dollars, but she feigns ignorance. A rowdy Jessica then emerges to state that Niki is lying. Soon, Jessica recommends the lawyer bring in a "[[psychologist|shrink]]" to analyze her apparent [[multiple personality disorder]]; Niki insists she's not crazy. Later, a meeting with D. L. and Micah indicates that D. L. gave Linderman back the two million dollars. D. L. regrets the whole situation, but Niki believes that it's for the best. She states that she still thinks of Jessica as a completely separate person and not an alter ego. Micah is very distressed by the whole situation and Niki asks the guard for permission to hug him. The guard denies her request, but Niki asks persistently, advancing on the guard as she does so. When the guard attempts to strike her with his [[Baton (law enforcement)|nightstick]], Niki grabs it and breaks it in half with her bare hands. She appears to be surprised after she does so, as there was no clear indication that the superhuman strength came from Jessica. A now [[straitjacket]]ed Niki is [[sedative|sedated]] and placed in a room with padded walls. In "[[The Fix (Heroes)|The Fix]]," Niki awakes to find the straitjacket removed, the drugs wearing off, and a psychologist, [[List of characters in Heroes#Dr. Witherson|Dr. Witherson]], looking at her. Niki insists that while the straitjacket is useless, the drugs make Jessica weak. The psychologist isn't interested in sedating Niki further, and believes she can help Niki. Niki is visited by D. L., who used his powers to enter her room and proposes breaking her out. D. L. states that he is having trouble raising Micah alone, but Niki is still resigned to her fate. After Niki gives him a bit of advice, D. L. leaves. Later, the psychologist comes back and Niki agrees to talk to her. The psychologist insists on talking to Jessica. Niki is opposed at first, but the thought of being able to see Micah and D. L. again eventually leads her to give it a chance. Niki reminisces about her sister Jessica's piano playing abilities due to the metronome that the psychologist is using to bring Jessica out. Jessica eventually comes out and attacks the psychologist repeatedly with the [[Taser]] that the other woman brought for protection. Later, while in her padded cell, a man walks into her cell and tells her to get dressed. When asked for an explanation, he tells Niki that a death row inmate has admitted to the killings for which she was being held and that DNA evidence verifies the inmate's story. Once home, Micah is clearly ecstatic to have his mother home and asks her to play a game with him. Appearing to be his mother, Jessica replies that she would enjoy that, and Niki is shown to be hitting a mirror, begging for release. Jessica merely looks at Niki and replies, "You were the one who wanted to be locked up, Niki." Jessica becomes Linderman's new assassin, and it is revealed that Linderman arranged to have Niki/Jessica released from prison. On Linderman's orders, Jessica kills a man by tearing him in two, throwing [[Matt Parkman]] ([[Greg Grunberg]]) out of the window in the process. (When Niki and Jessica are fighting for dominance when Jessica is about to kill the target, [[Matt Parkman]] who possesses the power of [[telepathy]], is able to hear them both in his mind, a fact which surprises Jessica. "You heard Niki?".) Niki manages to gain control a few times. She puts the photo of Nathan Petrelli, Jessica's next target, on D. L.'s pillow, which causes D. L. to question Jessica, who is still pretending to be Niki. Jessica lies and tells him that Linderman called to ask her to be a "dealer" at the casino. Jessica kisses D. L. and assures him that it is nothing more. He leaves the room but is still suspicious. Jessica murders the two FBI agents, who are working with Nathan to take down Linderman. Later, Niki, who has managed to gain control once again, confronts Nathan in his room and confesses everything to him. She then advises Nathan to either take his family and run or to accept Linderman's offer. Nathan refuses, so Niki suggests that he kill Linderman instead. She gives Nathan a gun, which Jessica had intended to use on him. She tells Nathan that she does not have much time and begs him to knock her out so that Jessica can see that she is not in control anymore. Nathan complies. In "[[.07%]]", Jessica returns home from her failed assignment only to be confronted by D. L who questions her about which personality is dominant. However, Jessica is unsure. Linderman asks if he can borrow Micah for a few hours, given that he let the debt slide and he saved her from the gas chamber. Jessica coldly informs him that Micah stays out of all their affairs, and leaves. Linderman, however, sends [[Candice Wilmer]] to impersonate Jessica and give Micah permission to go with Linderman. In "[[The Hard Part]]", Jessica and D. L. argue about their son Micah's whereabouts, and D. L. blames Jessica for his disappearance. He leaves, intending to rescue Micah without help. Niki pleads with Jessica to assist him, saying that he will die without her help. D. L. and Jessica phase through walls and into Linderman's office. They find detailed files on their whole family, including Micah. D. L. is angered to find that they had been used. The pair attempts to determine Micah's whereabouts, and find a painting of Micah in what appears to be a burning New York City. D. L. and Jessica make it to New York, where they work with [[Matt Parkman]] and [[Mr. Bennet (Heroes)|Mr. Bennet]] to find Linderman. When D. L. and Jessica corner him, Linderman offers Jessica $20 million to kill D. L. Jessica seriously considers the offer, turning to D.L. and saying that she would kill him for that amount of money... but then she states "Niki wouldn't" and lets Niki take control once more. Niki hugs D. L. and apologizes. Linderman shoots at her but D. L. anticipates him and steps in front of Niki to protect her, taking the bullet. D. L. phases Niki out of the room after he kills Linderman. Niki then confronts [[Candice Wilmer]], who impersonates Jessica. However, the real Jessica appears in a mirror shard to tell Niki she is not fighting her. Rather than take control, Jessica encourages Niki to fight herself and she is able to finally access her super strength as Niki and defeat Candice. Jessica then disappears from the mirror for good. As Niki later leaves the building with D. L., Molly, Mohinder, and Micah, she discovers [[Sylar]] and Peter in a showdown. When Sylar summons a parking meter with his telekinesis and strikes Peter down, Niki disarms him and slams his torso with the weapon. Peter, now capable of using Niki's super-strength, tells her to go back to her family. She does so, and then watches with D. L., Micah, and Molly Walker as Nathan flies Peter into the stratosphere to safely explode. ===Generations=== [[Image:Niki Faces Gina.jpg|200px|left|thumb|Niki faces Gina's reflection for the first time (''[[Four Months Ago...]]'')]] After the events in the season finale, Bob from The Company approaches Niki in fear other personalities may emerge. She refuses his treatment so that she can be with Micah and D. L., who survived a gunshot wound to the chest. She begins taking medication, but stops when she experiences unpleasant side effects. On what is meant to be her first day of work at a new job, Gina, a new personality, appears, sealing Niki away. When D. L. tracks down Gina in L.A., whom he believes to be Jessica, she is dancing with another man. Upon seeing D. L., Niki returns. The two begin to leave, exchanging declarations of love for each other, when the same man dancing with Gina shows up and suddenly shoots D. L., killing him. Niki and Micah then leave Las Vegas. Niki leaves Micah with Nana Dawson, a relative of D. L.'s, and travels to The Company to seek a cure for her condition. A promise of service is extracted as payment. In "[[Fight or Flight (Heroes)|Fight or Flight]]", she attacks a company worker and Bob, forcing Mohinder to shoot her with a Taser. When Mohinder offers to help her escape, she stops him, explaining that she came to the Company voluntarily and they are trying to help her ("I gave up my son to be here"). Later, in the episode "[[The Line (Heroes)|The Line]]", she joins Mohinder as his partner, claiming to be cured. When [[Maury Parkman]] mounts an assault on the Company, he manages to corrupt her by using her nightmares against her. To stop herself, she injects herself with a modified form of the Shanti virus, which is soon discovered to be immune to the antibodies in Mohinder's blood. In the present at the end of "[[Four Months Ago...]]" she is released into the general population. In "[[Truth and Consequences]]", Niki returns to Nana Dawson's house to be with Micah. One night, she gets a call from Mohinder saying he has found a cure and that he is coming to give it to her. She goes to tell Micah who is supposed to be sleeping, but finds an empty bed. In "[[Powerless (Heroes)|Powerless]]", Micah convinces her to help save Monica from the gang that kidnapped her. Niki succeeds in rescuing Monica, but is unable to escape herself as the building explodes. === Villains === In "[[One of Us, One of Them]]", Niki is revealed to have died. In "[[I Am Become Death]]", it is revealed that Niki, [[Tracy Strauss]], and [[List of characters in Heroes#Barbara|Barbara]] are identical triplets that were separated at birth and had their genes modified to give them superhuman abilities. ==Alternate future== In the graphic novel "[[List of Heroes graphic novels|Walls, Part 1]]", it is revealed that sometime after the explosion, Niki was placed in a prison for evolved humans and put under maximum security until [[Peter Petrelli]] and [[Hiro Nakamura]] rescued every prisoner, including her. She is also shown to have taken complete control over her body. Sometime after being freed in "[[Five Years Gone]]" it is revealed that her son and husband have been killed, Micah by the explosion and D. L. by Sylar. Because of this, Jessica has simply disappeared. Niki is involved in a relationship with [[Peter Petrelli]] and works as a barroom stripper under the stage name of "Jessica". She is often emotional and in pain, which only grows when she discovers that Peter caused the explosion and not Sylar, as she originally thought. == Powers and abilities == [[Image:Nikki's enhanced strength.jpg|180px|right|thumb|Jessica (Niki) easily lifts [[List of characters in Heroes#Bob Bishop|Bob Bishop]] in "[[Fight or Flight (Heroes)|Fight or Flight]]".]] Niki was not born with the genetic code for abilities, but was synthetically given powers under the Company's orders by [[List of characters in Heroes#Dr. Zimmerman|Dr. Zimmerman]]. She has the ability of enhanced strength, allowing her to pull out the door of a safe box with her bare hands,"[http://www.nbc.com/Heroes/novels/downloads/Heroes_novel_006.pdf Stolen Time] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061201093121/http://www.nbc.com/Heroes/novels/downloads/Heroes_novel_006.pdf |date=2006-12-01 }}," sixth chapter of [[List of Heroes graphic novels|''Heroes'' webcomic]]. throw her husband several feet across a small area with a single hit, break away from restraining cuffs that are "strong enough to hold down an elephant", and literally tear her opponents apart. She also displays signs of increased physical durability, being able to endure a blow from a shovel in "[[Fallout (Heroes)|Fallout]]", only to stand back up again relatively unharmed, as well as able to endure the stress inflicted upon her body by her own strength (she does not, for example, injure her hand when punching through a solid wooden door). The ability is originally only used by her alter-ego, Jessica. In "[[How to Stop an Exploding Man]]", however, Niki is able to fully use her strength after some encouragement from Jessica. As a side effect of her ability, Niki has [[Dissociative identity disorder#terms|"alternate" personalities]]. Jessica is one of these, named after Niki's late adoptive sister. At the start of the series, Jessica surfaces during times of great stress,[http://gregbeeman.blogspot.com/2006/10/episode-6-better-halves.html Episode 6: Better Halves], "Beaming Beeman," blog of Greg Beeman, Director/Producer of ''Heroes''. Retrieved 31 Oct 2006. but surfaces with increasing ease as the series moves on. When Jessica surfaces, the transformation is instantaneous and almost unnoticeable, but is made apparent by Niki's sudden violent and strong-willed behavior. Jessica also freely demonstrates the superhuman strength Niki has only recently unlocked. She also gains a peculiar [[tattoo]] resembling an [[RNA]] helix on her right shoulder. This [[Mythology of Heroes#Helix|helix symbol]] has been a recurring element in the series. Jessica seems to have been aware that she is sharing Niki's body for longer than Niki realizes, leaving notes, gifts, and instructions for Niki, and telling a thug not to "threaten ''our'' son." Niki becomes aware of Jessica with the aid of reflective surfaces such as mirrors, and begins communicating with her. Jessica's ability to surface seems to increase over time, as Jessica is able to actively surface more often and more easily than she does in early episodes. The blackout effect on Niki also seems to lessen over time; the two personalities often directly fight each other for control and seem aware of what is said even when they are not active. It is revealed in "[[Four Months Ago...]]" that Jessica is not Niki's only personality. A third personality emerges: Gina, a pseudonym Niki assumed after she ran away to L.A. when she was younger. Whereas Jessica was originally triggered by the stresses of being a single mother and the need to protect herself and Micah, Gina seems to be a manifestation of Niki's suppressed desire to escape her responsibilities as a mother and wife. == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Heroes}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sanders, Niki}} [[Category:Heroes (U.S. TV series) characters]] [[Category:Female characters in television]] [[Category:Fictional adoptees]] [[Category:Fictional assassins]] [[Category:Fictional characters from Las Vegas]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2006]] [[Category:Fictional characters with multiple personalities]] [[Category:Fictional characters with superhuman strength]] [[Category:Fictional erotic dancers]] [[Category:Fictional gamblers]] [[Category:Fictional genetically engineered characters]] [[Category:Fictional mass murderers]] [[Category:Fictional triplets]] [[Category:Fictional characters with alter egos]] [[pl:Postacie z serialu Herosi#Nicole "Niki" Sanders]]
